question.block.title: Wholesale Sales Tax on Motor Vehicles

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Short, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, are you aware of the requirements of section 130B of the Sales Tax Assessment Act? Are you aware that that section requires that `where a minister makes a public statement which announces that it is the intention of the government to introduce into a house of the parliament a bill relating to a sales tax law to operate from a date before the enactment of the bill, the commissioner must, within seven days of that minister making the statement, publish, for the information of taxpayers in each state and territory, a public notice, in plain English, in at least two newspapers circulating generally in that state or territory'?

answer.speaker: Short, Sen Jim

talk.start.para: —So far as the requirements of the tax act for the publication of sales tax or other tax change measures are concerned, they are ones of course that the government always has fully in mind. We will continue to do so. If you are referring to the Treasurer's announcement last week on 11 June relating to sales tax, that was an announcement in relation to the Premiers Conference that was forthcoming. It was a matter for discussion and consideration within the context of the Premiers Conference.

answer.para: I think you will find that has been done on numerous other occasions, and presumably it will continue to be done as is necessary in the future. But, so far as the requirements from the taxation commissioner are concerned, the fact is the Treasurer has announced that the necessary arrangements and announcements to put into effect legislatively the decisions that were finalised only last Friday will be done at the appropriate time.

talk.start.para:
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given that
the Treasurer is obliged to meet the statutory seven‐day deadline, which expires today, can you inform the Senate today in which newspapers your government has placed the required notice?
—I have nothing further to add to my first answer. I shall refer your supplementary question to the Treasurer as the responsible minister.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, most Australians are well aware of the benefits to Australia in general terms of investment in this country but could you explain the vital importance of major capital investment in Australia's natural heritage? Have you noticed any growing support for the government's proposals in this area?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para:
—I will deal with the second part of the question first. It is in fact pleasing to see more organisations coming out in support of the government's plan. That is not surprising because of the obvious merit. No doubt all honourable senators, in reading last weekend's
Weekend Australian
, would have noticed that the world's largest coastal environment group, the Surfrider Foundation, `demanded yesterday that Telstra be sold for the sake of the nation's environment'.

answer.para: Very interestingly, the announcement was made by Mr Brad Farmer, head of the Australian arm of Surfrider and a former adviser to the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Cheryl Kernot. He said:
For 18 years they (the Democrats) have been asking exactly, virtually to a T, what the Liberal Government is offering, and to decline it on these grounds is less than honest, I think.

That is true because for so long the Democrats and the Greens have called for a greater investment in the natural heritage of Australia, and now they have the opportunity to support it of course they intend to block it. It was also interesting to note that the Environment Management Industry Association of Australia came out in support of our natural heritage bill, to be introduced into the parliament tomorrow. Dr Cole of that organisation said:

break.para: Money, not good intentions and high sounding rhetoric, is what is required to protect and improve our environmental resource.

That says exactly what the situation is. The former government, the Labor Party, no doubt would have liked to have done more in this area as well because everyone recognises the need to re-invest in our natural environment.

I remind the Senate that over five million hectares of native vegetation were cleared within only 10 years between 1983 and 1993. I could remind the Senate also of those animals and birds that have become extinct, those mammals and plant species that are currently declining. I could talk about the state of our rivers, our seas, our coast. Everyone recognises that what is now necessary is a major capital investment.

This parliament has before it the opportunity to endorse the government's process and re-invest $1 billion in this program. Mr President, I remind you what will come out of that investment. Some $318 million over five years would be invested in a national vegetation initiative both to retard further clearing and to fund a very major revegetation program. About $32 million would be invested in a land and water resource audit. Some $163 million would be used for the Murray-Darling project; $85 million would be for the national river care initiative to pick up other rivers that are not covered by the Murray‐Darling initiative; and $100 million would be for the coast and clean seas initiative.

Everyone accepts that the time has come for us to pause and recognise the situation, and to reinvest a large capital sum in the natural environment. In so many ways it has been overworked, in so many ways it has been damaged—partly out of ignorance—and it can be rectified only by a large capital injection of funds.

We have the process to do that; we have the way to do it. All we need is for the Labor Party and the other minority parties to come on board and to recognise that this is an opportunity too good to miss, and to join with us in making this very major investment in Australia's natural heritage.

question.speaker: Sherry, Sen Nick

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Short, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, yesterday in this place you said, in answer to a question from Senator Chris Evans:

question.para: You wrecked an economy . . . You left us well below achieving the growth potential of this nation.
Minister, how do you reconcile these remarks with those of the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, who recently said:

The Australian economy continues by world standards to enjoy very strong growth and, in common with most of the OECD countries, we have lower levels of inflation and we continue to enjoy the benefits.
Minister, will you undertake to point out to the Prime Minister where he was wrong?

answer.speaker: Short, Sen Jim

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister was not wrong. The fact is that the Australian economy is growing robustly at the moment. We welcome that—we always have welcomed that. We have said, though, that the Australian economy could have been doing a darn sight better over recent years had it had some responsible economic management, which was disastrously lacking when Labor was in office.

answer.para: Look at a few comparisons in the context of the economy growing robustly at the moment. When Labor came to office in 1983, the foreign debt of this country was $23 billion. Today it is $180 billion plus. In the last four years alone, Commonwealth debt has increased despite the fact that the economy has been growing. It has increased fivefold to $84 billion from a figure just four years ago of $16 billion. Indeed, total Commonwealth debt today is a massive $93 billion.

For the last three to four years, including the projection for next year, the accumulated bottom line deficit of Labor governments will total a monstrous $40 billion. That is the reason why interest rates are far higher than they should be. That is the reason why unemployment is so much higher than it should be. That is the reason why, compared with our major competitor nations around the world, particularly those in South‐East Asia, we are doing badly.

break.para: All of those things are solvable. They should never have happened in the first place. They were due to the mismanagement of the former government and that is precisely the reason why, to use the words of your former Treasurer, Ralph Willis, just two to three weeks ago, `Labor lost the trust of the Australian people'.

You lost the trust of the Australian people because under your regime you squandered the great opportunities for growth and development that this country has. The mandate for the present government, which we have set out in a very active and vigorous way to fulfil, is to restore hope, confidence, opportunity and growth to the Australian people and the Australian economy.

talk.start.para: —Yet again, Senator Short, you have failed to answer the question. Have you read the Prime Minister's comments? Do you agree with them? Why do you continue to contradict the Prime Minister on the excellent economic growth of Australia?

—There is no contradiction at all between my comments and the Prime Minister's. As I said, the Prime Minister is totally correct in saying that the Australian economy is in a robust situation. The point I am making is that for the last 10 years, particularly the last four years of economic growth, the then Labor government squandered the enormous opportunities it had to put Australia onto a really sustainable, long‐term growth path. That is what we are on about totally.

question.speaker: Patterson, Sen Kay

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to Senator Richard Alston, the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, no doubt you remember the challenge that Senator Kernot put to you in her speech on the adjournment on 29 May regarding benefits to the United Kingdom consumers resulting from the British Telecom privatisation experience. I quote:

question.para: So let Senator Alston come in here and quote from something else other than British Telecom's figures, because what we need to point out is that reliance on one source like that forms a very small part of the story.

Minister, I am sure you can rise to the challenge, and I ask you to provide Senator Kernot and the Senate with third party evidence that shows that British consumers have benefited from a 40 per cent price reduction since the privatisation in 1984.

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —I am sorry that Senator Kernot is not in the chamber. I presume she is still out surfing the net and checking on our figures.
—She is at the memorial service in Perth, Richard, with John Howard and Kim Beazley.

—No doubt when she does return she will be able to absorb some of the information that I think is critically missing from the current debate. I have to confess that I have not yet heard from Fidel. I presume that his fax has not got through because of congestion on the line or because he cannot afford the high prices that are charged in Australia for international access.

answer.para: What Senator Kernot challenged me to a month or two back—on 29 May, in fact—was to come into this chamber with some independent figures. In other words, she did not accept the validity of the BT figures which I tabled in this chamber. She, I think, was asking for some third party verification.

The fact is that Oftel, which is the regulator upon which Austel in this country is based, has recently released a paper called
Pricing of Telecommunications Services from 1997
. This gives a history of what has occurred in the United Kingdom following privatisation. Senator Kernot seems to be under the impression that price caps were only introduced into the UK in 1993. The fact is that they have had price caps there since 1984, and changes to that price capping regime in 1993 were pretty much in line with the changes that have occurred in this country.

Oftel reports that, since the first price cap in 1984, BT's prices have fallen on average by 40 per cent in real terms, while BT's efficiency has increased overall by an average of 3.5 per cent a year in real terms. They also say quality of service has improved significantly both in terms of network quality through substantial investment and new
technology in customer service, and BT has continued to earn an adequate return on capital.

They also say that for prices across all areas, from local calls at peak time to off-peak to national and international rates, the reductions on average have been about 40 per cent. They outline significant reductions in residential line rentals and business line rentals. Indeed, the prices have only increased by about half the inflation rate. Meanwhile, connection charges have fallen in real terms for residential consumers by 6.3 per cent and for businesses by 36.9 per cent. Local calls have fallen by 47.3 per cent, and standard call charges have fallen by 35.7 per cent.

I could go on and on, but the fact remains that there is some very good news coming out of the UK. It is very disappointing that Senator Kernot seems to want to be the Hanrahan of the Senate and pretend that somehow we will all be `rooned' if we do what the rest of the world is doing. There is no-one left. Once Albania went, I would have thought the game was up. With South Africa now prepared to speed up the privatisation process, there really is not anyone left in this game who wants to run this sort of line.

That is why I think it is very important to understand why the Democrats are doing it. Do they argue that, if the UK had not privatised, you would have had even more substantial reductions in prices and increases in quality of service, or do they seriously contest the proposition, as every other independent observer would contend, that it is the combination of all these things that makes the difference? Unless you have privatisation accompanying the rest, you will not get anything like the benefits they have derived in the UK.

That is about the only difference. We have got price caps; they have got price caps. They have got competition; we have got competition. In fact, we go further with untimed local calls and the consumer safeguards regime, and yet we are very much off the world pace—about 30 per cent, according to Telstra's own assessments.

Why is it that we are lagging the rest of the world and BT has been able to outperform,
and British consumers have been able to reap a bonanza? The answer is that it is a combination of all these things. If privatisation was a real hindrance in that process, then, of course, they would be much better off, and I doubt that even the Democrats would argue that.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short. Minister, in view of your answer to my earlier question about your proposed sales tax changes and the clear implication that your government has failed to meet its statutory obligations, I ask: will you give an assurance that penalties will not be imposed on car dealers who might unwittingly incur them through your government's incompetence in this matter?

—For Senator Faulkner to call this side of the chamber incompetent is the height of gall. As I said in response to your earlier question, I will refer the question to the Treasurer. I do not accept the proposition that the government has not met its statutory responsibilities but, as I said before, I shall refer it to the Treasurer.
—Can Senator Short tell the Senate when the government will provide the further details that were foreshadowed in last Friday's press release after the Premiers Conference?

—As I said, and I say it yet again to Senator Faulkner, at the conclusion of the Premiers Conference last Friday, the Treasurer announced that the details and the legislative requirements, so far as the sales tax changes and other matters emanating from the Premiers Conference were concerned, will be introduced and announced at the earliest possible opportunity.

—My question is addressed to Senator Hill representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I am sure the minister is aware of the continuing and, in fact, worsening human rights situation in Burma, and the fact that the SLORC has placed further restrictions on pro-democracy
leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her supporters from engaging in political meetings and gatherings. Given this appalling situation, will the minister, firstly, give assurances that the coalition government will maintain the embargo on the export of defence and defence related goods to Burma? Secondly, will the minister advise whether the government is now considering supporting Burma's entrance into ASEAN?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable senator for her question and her continuing interest in Burma's human rights issues—as I do, Mr President, your interest and Senator Reid's and, once upon a time, Senator Schacht's.

answer.para: All of us who have protested the loss of democracy, one at the ballot box and the other lost at the point of a gun—the continuing situation of political prisoners' labour circumstances that cannot be characterised other than as forced labour—remain disturbed and disappointed that so little progress has been made to improve the human rights situation in Burma.

I think, Senator Bourne, from time to time we see some modest signs of hope—only to see them so quickly dashed. In the lead‐up to the recent convention of the National League for Democracy, there were many arrests, which caused great international concern as well as concern within Burma. Nevertheless, the convention was able to go ahead, and we thought perhaps that was a positive sign for the future. Then there were some signs that the detainees were starting to be released, and we thought that was perhaps a modest positive sign for the future. But then we had our hopes dashed by, as you say, a further clampdown: the proclamation of a law that provides for draconian penalties of up to 20 years imprisonment for individuals and suspension or abolition of organisations expressing political dissent that can be characterised as undermining peace or stability. Therefore, the chances of further conventions, such as the one that was allowed to take place, are very unlikely.

As you know, Senator Bourne, the international community has wrestled for a long time as to what is the best mix of policies to try to
influence change for the better in Burma. Whether they have been the ASEAN type policies of engagement or whether they have been policies more akin to that of Australia—and the United States, in particular, in many ways has led the alternative of providing limitations upon trade or other contact—neither formula, unfortunately, has produced the results that we would like to see. Certainly the new Australian government will maintain the embargo on the export of defence and defence related goods to Burma.

The issue of whether Burma enters ASEAN remains, we believe, an issue for ASEAN to determine. As I said a moment ago, ASEAN, in trying to influence a better outcome in these matters, has sought to adopt a somewhat different approach. Our intention is to very much continue with the policies that this country has now pursued for some time of setting benchmarks and, when we can see positive signs of progress, of giving some reward and encouragement to those positive signs. We certainly do not want to get ahead of the game and give encouragement that would suggest that the international community is going to accept the legitimacy of Burma's regime whilst it continues to oppress its people in the way that it currently does.

talk.start.para: —I thank the minister for that answer, which I do find somewhat encouraging. He did mention trade in his answer to me. Could I further ask the minister: is the issue of whether Australia should encourage or discourage trade between Australian companies and those within Burma still on the agenda, and is it something that the government is still considering?

—Again, I should check with Minister Downer, but I do not believe we have changed the position from that of the previous government, which was not to encourage it because we would like to see further change first. But, as you would know, Senator Bourne, there is now very major investment occurring within Burma and there is a very major inflow of goods and services. Therefore, one wonders. I certainly wonder whether any restraints on trade, even if they are only in terms of expressed sentiment, are really going to make much difference. The
approach of Australia has for some time been a cautious approach because, as I said, we have not wanted to give the impression that in any way actions of our government would give legitimacy to the behaviour of the SLORC. That rather cautious approach, we believe, remains the best choice open to our country.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I ask: does the abolition of the NBEET and its councils require the repeal of section 6 of the Employment, Education and Training Act? Were you unaware of this when you wrote to the council chairpersons seeking their consent to wind up various NBEET councils or were you trying to circumvent the act?

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for his question. Legislation to deal with the abolition of NBEET will be introduced into parliament next week, and all will be revealed for you.

—I direct my question to the Assistant Treasurer. Is it true that the former Labor government left the Australian people a legacy of ballooning public debt and that Labor had a 13‐year window of opportunity to do something constructive on public debt but chose to do nothing about it? What will be the benefit for the average Australian of the reduction in public debt resulting from all Australians being given the opportunity to purchase, and directly own, part of Telstra?

answer.speaker: Short, Sen Jim

talk.start.para:
—I thank Senator Chapman for his question. The answer, of course, to the first part of his question is an unequivocal yes. The former government did leave a legacy of ballooning debt to the Australian people and, of course, to future generations of Australians. That question from Senator Chapman really goes to the whole heart of what the government with its debt reduction strategy is all about. What it is all about is trying to repair the huge damage to the structure of the government's finances that occurred under the 13 years of Labor and to get the government's books back into the
black. The legacy of Labor's debt to the Australian people is arguably one of the greatest legacies that any political party in government has left to the people.

answer.para: In the last four years alone, as I said in response to an earlier question, despite the fact that there was growth in the economy and despite the fact that the government should have been in surplus rather than in deficit, the Labor government racked up deficit after deficit after deficit. The net result is that over the last four years the total of Commonwealth general government debt increased almost fivefold from more than $16 billion to almost $84 billion, and total Commonwealth debt blew out to a monstrous figure of $93 billion.

The result of that in terms of the bottom line on the budget is that the taxpayers of Australia have to meet increasingly large interest bills on the money borrowed by government. Interest payments are now something like the fourth or fifth largest of all Commonwealth government payments. That is why the legacy of debt is such an important question. The incredible thing is that Labor has never ever understood the simple fact that, if governments keep putting their hands in the jars of the nation's savings, they reduce the living standards of all Australians.
We have almost the lowest savings rate as a nation that we have had in our history and it is possible that the household savings rate will actually become negative in the next year or so.

talk.start.para: —Why don't you talk about housewives being kicked out, as Senator Newman did?

—Senator Schacht, Senator Bolkus and some of their colleagues seem to think that that is funny and not a matter for serious concern. There is no more serious matter for concern facing the economy of Australia. The partial privatisation of one‐third of Telstra is a very important component because it would reduce the Commonwealth's debt by $7 billion. Therefore, it would reduce the amount of taxes that Australians need to spend on interest repayments by several hundred million dollars and it would help put the finances of the nation back on a sound
footing after the vandalism that has occurred over the last 13 years of Labor rule.

—My question is addressed to Senator Newman, representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Given the government's intention to hand over responsibility for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to the states, will the minister guarantee that all Australians will have access to all the drugs they need?

—I would have thought the opposition, by now, would have realised that it is not much use to be continually running up questions in this place based on speculation in the media. Even more certainly, it is not much use if it is related to the budget process, which, as some of the more senior senators on the opposition benches would well know, is not going to be announced prior to the budget.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Assuming that in the budget the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is transferred to the states, will there need to be eight different evaluation bodies in each state to determine—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question is clearly hypothetical and hypothetical questions are out of order.
—I uphold the point of order. That is a fact. The question is hypothetical the way it has been framed. Reframe it if you want to.
—Well, therefore I ask—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You will recall that during a question time Senator MacGibbon from Queensland was ruled to have asked a particular question. I raised a point of order suggesting that you invite Senator MacGibbon to rephrase his question in a way that would not be contrary to standing orders. You said to me that you could not do it. Yet when a Labor senator does it, you somehow invite them to rephrase the question. What is the standard in this place?

—You will remember I actually did invite Senator MacGibbon to
rephrase his question once I had read the
Hansard
. I believed up to that point I had made the correct judgment. Senator Neal, if you want to, rephrase your question. Certainly, it is hypothetical the way it is.
—Will the government's plans require—and it is not hypothetical because comment has been made by the state ministers in relation to those plans—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. In line with your ruling, if she gets it wrong this time, will Senator Neal get a third and fourth chance? How many chances will she get?
—Sit down. Senator Neal.

—Will the government's plans mean that there will be eight different evaluation bodies to determine which drugs are listed on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and what will this duplication cost the people of Australia?
—Mr President, a hypothetical question by any other name is still a hypothetical. There is no getting away from it, Senator. You could not get a chance to rephrase it—it is still a hypothetical.

question.speaker: O'Chee, Sen Bill

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy.

question.para:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —When the rabble on the other side ceases—
—Order! It is not your place to be calling the other side—
—Mr President, these people do not want to hear the question and they do not want to hear the answer.

question.para:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! Take your seat! This is becoming a joke and we will suspend question time if it continues.

—My question is to the minister for resources. I refer him to the decision last night—and it may interest Senator Murphy and his union mates over there—by the CFMEU to take strike action at Dalrymple Bay coal terminal in Queensland
in refusing to load coal exports from MIM, CRA and Shell mines. I ask the minister: what damage will this premeditative strike action have in terms of Australia's exports, what message does it send to Australia's trading partners and what impact will it have on Australia's business profile overall? You might want to take an interest in this, Senator Murphy.

answer.speaker: Parer, Sen Warwick

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank Senator O'Chee for that question. The genesis of this stupid and unnecessary strike is a decision by the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission to give coverage of the Dalrymple Bay coal terminal to the AWU rather than the CFMEU. Rather than accept the umpire's decisions, the CFMEU is thumbing its nose at the court and putting a deadline on the users of the port to support the CFMEU or accept the industrial consequences—typical blackmail that we have been used to in the past. There has already been since then the refusal to load a shipment of coal from one of the users of Dalrymple Bay at Port Kembla.

answer.para: The CFMEU, as everyone knows, is going through an internal power struggle and is engaging in blatant blackmail through a secondary boycott now. The dispute is one to do with coverage and the CFMEU is engaged in a form of industrial blackbirding. It is quite apparent that the CFMEU is neither interested in the well-being of its own members or in Australia as a nation.

The CFMEU will be further aware that in engaging in and threatening further action they will yet again raise the spectre in the minds of overseas buyers of reliability of supply. The result of this has always been diversification of supply from buyers which in turn means attack on our balance of payments, our foreign debt and of course the unemployment position.

The CFMEU wrote to various users of the Dalrymple Bay coal terminal. It is interesting to see the new politically correct language being used. Here we have the strike at Dalrymple Bay simply because of a demarcation dispute. They do not call it a strike. Do you know what they call it in the letter to the
companies? They say, `We are currently taking protected industrial action.' How about that for political correctness!

talk.start.para: —What is the new word for `scab'?
—You should know with the pilots dispute, Robert. You appointed enough of them.
—Order! There are too many interjections on both sides.
—They then go on to say:

answer.para: Since the protected industrial action commenced, local management have acted in a foolhardy fashion by refusing to discuss the matter with the union and seeking orders of the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission for return to work.
What a dreadful thing to do! What an appalling thing to do! The next bit is even better:
Further, local management have written directly to employees.
What right has the company got to write directly to employees!

talk.start.para: —Well, they have to cop the consequences then.

—Senator Burns has hit the nail on the head. Senator Burns says, `Let them cop the consequences.' This is the sort of action which makes it absolutely imperative that the government legislation on industrial relations which was foreshadowed prior to the last election is implemented with great speed for the benefit of the Australian economy.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What impact will this have on jobs if the CFMEU succeeds in its plan to obviously undermine Australia's coal exports?

answer.speaker: Parer, Sen Warwick

talk.start.para:
—This is a very serious matter because the coal exports of Australia are our greatest export earner. Over the years we have seen the industry grow both in respect of coking coal for steel making and steaming coal for power generation. The vast majority of coal that comes out of Dalrymple Bay to which Senator O'Chee refers is coking coal and it is a high quality coking coal used in the steel mills in many countries around the world. I think there is something over 30
or 40 countries now using that. I know there are countries like Japan, Korea, Taiwan, India, Brazil, the Netherlands, and so on.

answer.para:
With the union going down that track they put at risk, as we have said over and over again, the reliability of supply. I notice Senator Cook does not interject on this because he is aware of the particular intransigence, I think the word is, of this particular union on matters such as this. However, we do have the capacity in this country because of the high qualities in our coal to increase our exports. They are putting that at risk.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, you would be aware that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has recently made a statement saying that he has the strong support of the Prime Minister for statehood for the Northern Territory. You would also be aware of the absolutely crucial role that Aboriginal issues will play constitutionally in that road to statehood and you would also be aware that the preferred root of statehood for the Northern Territory is by an act of this parliament. That being the case, can you advise the Senate if you support the proposal that the preamble to that act should recognise the prior occupation and ownership by the Aboriginal peoples of the Northern Territory before European settlement? Do you support the proposal to have the Commonwealth 1976 Land Rights Act enshrined in that act as organic law?

answer.ministerial: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs
answer.speaker: Herron, Sen John

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Collins for the question. It is a very important one. It has been discussed and mentioned in the media. Senator Collins, you will be aware that the Fraser government instituted the 1976 land act which was of vital importance. There are about to be celebrations in that regard and we will certainly be supporting those as the act was a coalition initiative.
—It was Big Mal; he was very strong on those issues.

—It was; and he is still very proud of that fact. He will be invited
back to the Northern Territory when those celebrations occur. You are aware that not only did the Commonwealth government support the Northern Territory's movement towards statehood but so did the states. It is still up for discussion as to when that should occur and the details of that. I am sure that will occur in the progress of time.

answer.para: Certainly in my visits to the Northern Territory—and you might be interested to know that I have been to Alice Springs on two occasions and Tangentyere and the out-stations as well as Kununurra, Port Hedland, Jigalong, Warburton, Perth—

talk.start.para: —They are in Western Australia.

—They are in Western Australia but I am just announcing where I have been in that period of time—Thursday Island, Warraber, Badu Island, Boigu Islands, York Islands, Yuendumu, Port Keats, Daly River, Kakadu and Darwin. I might tell you in none of those areas were those questions asked. I think Senator Collins ought to accompany me, because after 13 years of Labor neglect—
—What has that got to do with it?

—It has got to do with where the Aboriginal community is today after 13 years of your government. They are not questions that are going to influence the outcome of Aboriginal communities. That is the importance of that question. If it is to the benefit of the Aboriginal community, then certainly I support it. It is in that context that I am mentioning those other areas that I have been to.
—So you do support the concept.
—Yes.

—This is an important concept, as Senator Herron says. Both of the proposals I have raised today are things Aboriginal organisations do want. Whether or not they have actually asked Senator Herron those questions I do not think is particularly relevant, but they do want the preamble to contain those provisions and they do want the 1976 Land Rights Act enshrined
as organic law in the constitution. Can I get clarification of your last answer? Do you, by your answer, indicate your support for both of those propositions?

answer.ministerial: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs
answer.speaker: Herron, Sen John

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Norway has recently doubled the quota for its annual hunt of minke whales and Japan is set to continue its annual kill of whales for so-called scientific purposes. As senators would be aware, the Fraser coalition government led the way in pushing for an international ban on commercial whaling. Minister, can you inform the Senate of the Howard government's position on whaling?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable senator for his question. It is true that the International Whaling Commission will meet in Aberdeen next week and the government has instructed its delegation to pursue positions that are consistent with our policy statement; that is, the objective of the implementation of a permanent international ban on commercial whaling.

answer.para:
We are proud, as the coalition, that it was the Fraser government which led the way in pushing for an international ban on commercial whaling, and we intend to pursue that same policy with vigour now that we are back in government. This is set to a disturbing background, which was touched upon in the question of Senator Crane; that is, Norway has recently doubled its kill of minke whales
and Japan's so-called scientific take is now up to some 540 minke whales. To that background, we have instructed our delegation not to vote in support of the proposed revised management procedures. Although it might be argued that those procedures will provide for the taking of whales at a lesser rate than perhaps some other formulas, nevertheless we believe that to enter into that debate could in fact be inconsistent with the ultimate objective that we are seeking; that is, the permanent international ban. We have instructed our delegation accordingly.

We have also instructed the delegation to vote in support of a ban on the electric lance method of killing whales. We will be voting in that instance together with Britain and New Zealand. We have instructed the delegation to oppose any proposal for an aboriginal take of whales not based on clearly demonstrated evidence of subsistence need. In that instance, in particular, we are concerned by a US proposal for the Makah Indian tribe to be allowed a take of grey whales, some five whales, for so-called cultural reasons. In that instance the claim is not even being made that it is for subsistence need, and this particular tribe, the Makah Indians, have not taken whales for some 70 years. So we believe that would be a significant step in the wrong direction, and we have instructed our delegation to indicate that through our vote.

We have further asked our delegation to call on Norway to abandon its annual minke whale hunt; to express the government's strong opposition to Japan's `scientific take' of whales; to reaffirm the government's support of the southern ocean whale sanctuary established under the IWC; and to continue to promote non‐lethal research into whales.

We believe that, by pursuing the positions I have just outlined, we will be sending a clear signal to the international community that this new Australian government is serious about seeking, and moving towards, the implementation of a permanent international ban on commercial whaling, which is long overdue.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Minister for the Environment. My question concerns Coode Island which, for those people who live outside Victoria, is an island very close to the centre of Melbourne where dangerous chemicals are stored. It was the scene some years ago of a fire. Is the federal government going to help the Victorian government to reallocate the chemical complex that is on Coode Island to some other place?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —Senator Cooney no doubt knows the history of this matter which was, as I understand, that after a fire some five years ago it was decided that the chemical storage complex in suburban Melbourne was inappropriately located and should therefore be moved. In the first instance I think it was suggested that it should move to Point Wilson. The former Australian government, the Labor government, decided that Point Wilson might be better used for an armaments depot. Then the suggestion was put that it should move to Point Lillias. That has been under consideration for some time. There has been an environmental impact process taking place by the Victorian authorities and endorsed by the Commonwealth. It was designated by the Commonwealth under the EPIP act.

answer.para: There are two major concerns of the Commonwealth. The first is that it is likely to impact upon the correct Ramsar listed wetland. As you know, there have been very few instances in which wetland boundaries have been changed. The second concern of the Commonwealth, which was put to the environmental process by ANCA, both in writing and orally, was the problem of the endangered species the orange‐bellied parrot, which uses this land space during the winter. As I understand it, it breeds in the wilderness areas of the south‐west of Tasmania and then, as the temperature declines in Tasmania, moves to the southern mainland states, in particular, Victoria and this area. There are very few pairs of this parrot left in existence today. Therefore we have very serious concerns as to its wellbeing.

break.para: That environmental assessment process is nearing a completion. The Victorian government has not made a decision upon it. We continue to express to it our concerns about both those issues, the wetlands in general and the orange‐ bellied parrot. I hope that we will endeavour to see whether there is a formula that could allow both objectives. That is the approach we are pursuing at the moment in a constructive and sensible way.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think it is on the record that Senator Hill has done a lot of good work in this area, particularly with the parrot. Are you willing to perhaps disagree with the Premier—who does tend to take a different view from that taken by you—if you think it proper to do so, given his attitude to what I think is a very important environmental area?
—Is it true that the Victorian Premier described the orange‐bellied parrot as a trumped up corella?

—I did hear that the Victorian Premier might have suggested that it was a trumped up corella. I think that that is just an example of Jeff's sense of humour. I know him to be a sensitive environmentalist who would be just as concerned about the wellbeing of this endangered species as every individual senator in this place.

—My question is to Senator Herron, Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Given the legacy of 13 years of neglect and mismanagement of Aboriginal programs by the Hawke‐Keating Labor governments, what is the Howard coalition government doing to ensure that steps are being taken to improve accountability within Aboriginal organisations?

answer.ministerial: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs
answer.speaker: Herron, Sen John

talk.start.para:
—I thank Senator Panizza for the question. After 13 years of Labor neglect, conditions in Aboriginal communities have not improved. Funding has not been getting through to indigenous people, and successive Labor governments have chosen to ignore the fact—just as they are today in opposition. As a result, health standards and
infrastructure in many indigenous communities are a disgrace.

answer.para: Infant mortality in the Aboriginal population is two to three times that of non‐Aboriginal children. Life expectancy is 16 to 19 years shorter than for the rest of the population. Approximately 14,000 dwellings are still required to meet housing needs in urban, rural and remote locations. In October last year, 120 remote Aboriginal communities did not have adequate water supply systems; 134 communities lacked appropriate sewage disposal systems; and 250 communities had no electricity. After 13 years, that is the record of the Labor government.

Many indigenous people are living in Third World conditions because the previous government failed to make sure that funding was reaching the people. I have visited a number of disadvantaged communities, as I have already mentioned, over the last three month. It is a shame that those opposite, who are the loudest in their criticism, cannot accompany me there to see them. Then they would be quiet. They would be silent and they would be ashamed.

In addition, Aboriginal legal services were in disarray, depriving many prisoners of adequate legal representation. This government will not let this condition continue. We announced recently that a special auditor would be appointed to improve accountability in Aboriginal organisations and, ultimately, outcomes for indigenous peoples. Special auditors KPMG started work last week. They will have the opportunity to look at approximately 6,000 grants to 2,000 recipient bodies. The special auditor has been appointed to enable the government to follow the money trail and ensure that funds are getting through to indigenous communities. There has obviously been a serious problem for many years, and we are taking steps to rectify the situation.

As I mentioned previously, I visited more communities in Western Australia last week and again saw many examples of areas that have not received adequate funding. People are actually suffering. Previously, the Office of Evaluation and Audit was constrained in its ability to trace the money trail. It did not have
the power to stop grants where there was a breach of requirements. The special auditor will be able to fill in these gaps. This is the first step in the enormous task of improving conditions for Aboriginal people.

question.block.title: Wholesale Sales Tax on Motor Vehicles

speech.speaker: Faulkner, Sen John

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), to a question without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to the publication of a notice of intention to introduce retrospective sales tax legislation into the parliament.

We have just heard Senator Short say that he really did not have to answer the question I
asked because, of course, I got the timing all wrong. Let me refer you, Senator Short, to the communique, the press release, that was issued by Mr Costello after the Premiers Conference concluded. Under the subheading `Application of wholesale sales tax to general purpose road vehicles' it says:

Wholesale sales tax will apply to general purpose road vehicles provided wholly or partly for private use as part of remuneration by Commonwealth, state, territory and local governments to take effect from the 11th June 1996.
It then says:
Further details will be announced as soon as possible.

We have more incompetence and ineptitude from this government on this issue. Not only have we seen in the Premiers Conference an absolutely humiliating backdown from Mr Costello and the government; not only have we seen Commonwealth‐state relations plunge to the lowest ebb ever after the Premiers Conference; not only have we seen a complete debacle of a Premiers Conference, but we have now seen a complete abrogation of Mr Costello's statutory obligations under section 130B of the Sales Tax Assessment Act.

And for the benefit of you, Senator Short, who do not seem to have any knowledge about this act—though, I might say, this is a surprise because it was Senator Short himself who is recorded as being present in a division in this chamber on 29 June 1995, when this very section gained passage in this chamber during debate on the taxation laws amendment bill which was part of the budget measures of 1995. Senator Short was here. He voted for it, but he does not know about it.

talk.start.para: —He is the Assistant Treasurer, God help us all.

—He is temporarily the Assistant Treasurer. That is true, Senator Collins. I make this public prediction that Mr Howard will take from him his responsibilities as the minister in this chamber representing the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance. I make that public prediction: he will lose those responsibilities before the conclusion of this parliament.
—I'll bet you five bucks.

—You're on. Let me read section 130B into the
Hansard
record. Under the heading `Information for the protection of taxpayers' section 130B says:

break.para: Where a Minister makes a public statement which announces that it is the intention of the Government to introduce into a House of the Parliament a bill relating to a sales tax law to operate from a date before the enactment of the bill, the Commissioner must, within 7 days of that Minister making the statement, publish, for the information of taxpayers in each State and Territory, a public notice, in plain English, in at least 2 newspapers circulating generally in that State or Territory, as the case may be, which shall include the following:

(a)
a statement of the intention of the Commonwealth Government to introduce the bill;

(b)
details of what the bill will contain and how and when its provisions will be applied, if and when it comes into force;

(c)
a warning that the bill is subject to enactment by both Houses of the parliament and, if enacted, is to operate retrospectively from a date or dates specified in the bill;

(d)
an explanation of why it is necessary that the bill be enacted retrospectively; and

(e)
details of hotlines, addresses or other sources from which taxpayers may obtain further information.

Mr Costello, Senator Short and this government have failed to fulfil their statutory obligations on this matter. They have been exposed in question time today in the Senate and the House of Representatives, and they stand condemned for this debacle.

speech.speaker: Short, Sen Jim

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer)

talk.start.para: —Senator Faulkner has simply got it wrong. He obviously cannot read, or if he can read, he cannot understand what the Sales Tax Assessment Act says. Nor can he understand, nor is he apparently prepared to quote fully from, the statement that was made at the conclusion of the Premiers Conference. I will quote it again. It said:

speech.para: Wholesale sales tax will apply to general purpose road vehicles provided wholly or partly for private use as part of remuneration by Commonwealth, state, territory and local governments to take effect from 11th June 1996. Further details will be announced as soon as possible.
That is what he quoted. He conveniently forgot or omitted to quote the next sentence, which said:
The Commonwealth has undertaken not to proceed with the withdrawal of the WST exemption in relation to other items canvassed in its offer of 11 June and the Treasurer's associated press release.

In other words, on 14 June the Treasurer was saying, `Here is a final agreement, reached after negotiation and consultation with the states. It is an agreement as of today—that is, Friday, 14 June—even though it were to take effect from three days earlier.' There is a huge difference between the date of effect of a measure and the date on which the statement is made. Time and again you have statements that are made in this parliament and elsewhere that will take effect from a different date. That is precisely the case in relation to this matter.

I do not have section 130B of the Sales Tax Assessment Act in front of me, but as I understand from what you read, Senator Faulkner, it says—correct me if I am wrong—`within seven days of the minister making the statement' and then the necessary follow through with the press announcements and so on. The fact is that the minister made the statement in relation to the agreement that was eventually reached on Friday, 14 June. I am sure that anyone with any knowledge of the law—I do not know whether Senator Faulkner does or not, but I see Senator Cooney looking wise over there, and I would be interested to hear his view—would know that the statement can only be the statement that relates to the date on which the agreed announcement is made. It is quite clear and unequivocal that Friday, 14 June is the operative date. That is certainly what the taxation commissioner believes and that is certainly the date from which the taxation commissioner is working. If I have to put my money on whether it is Senator Faulkner or the taxation commissioner who is right in the interpretation of the tax act, it is no contest.

Senator Faulkner, I do not know where you are getting your advice from nowadays. I do not know whether it is coming from Senator Sherry or some of your other whiz‐kids on your back bench. I suggest that you change
your team because you are under a bit of a threat as leader, if what they tell me is correct. I see Senator Ray sitting up there on the back bench, the grey eminence, pulling all the strings in this chamber day after day—not only here but elsewhere, too, I understand. You are a bit under threat. If I were you, I would be changing my advisers because I do not think you have too many more opportunities to get it as wrong as you are getting it at the moment, particularly in relation to this matter today.

speech.speaker: Sherry, Sen Nick

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —Let us just go, firstly, to the Treasurer's press release of 11 June, where he said:

speech.para: The removal of the wholesale sales tax exemption for general purpose road vehicles purchased or leased by Commonwealth, state and local governments is to have immediate effect. Effective from 3.15 p.m. AEST—
in fact, to the second, seven days ago. Then we have the follow-up press release which narrows down the removal of the tax exemption. It says:

Wholesale sales tax will apply to general purpose road vehicles provided wholly or partly for private use as part of remuneration by Commonwealth, state, territory and local governments to take effect from 11 June 1996.

The original announcement was made on 11 June, albeit narrowed down on the Friday, after the fracas that occurred at the Premiers Conference. The announcement by the government was made on 11 June to take effect from 11 June. As I said a moment ago, the seven days was up one minute ago.

As Senator Faulkner has pointed out, the amendments to the sales tax, passed on 29 June 1995, make it very clear that they refer to the period within seven days of the minister making the statement. Now we would argue that it should be the original statement, not just because it was the first statement made but also because that is the date on which the announcement was to take effect, which was reconfirmed on the Friday.

Senator Short was asked two questions on this matter today. As usual, he could not answer the two questions that were put to him
about this very specific sales tax matter. He then got further advice from his office, obviously, and he supplemented his so-called answers to the two questions at the end of question time. But he has still clearly got it wrong. The date of announcement of the sales tax exemption removals was 11 June—slightly more than seven days ago. It is very clear.

The then opposition voted for this measure some two years ago. Senator Short himself voted for the measure. They are now trapped by a measure of their own making. What they have done by failing to abide by that seven‐day notice period and the various qualifications in the amendment that they supported is make an illegal announcement about a sales tax change.

talk.start.para: —That is nonsense.
—The sales tax change was announced last Tuesday; it was to take effect from last Tuesday.
—You cannot interpret the act.

—Well, Senator Short, you read the act here. There is a whole range of criteria that you fail to meet as a government. At least two newspapers are circulating in the states and territories details of what the bill will contain and how and when its provisions will apply. Where are all these details warning that the bill is subject to enactment by both houses?
—Ask some of the big accountancy firms what they think about this, Jim.

—We had an accountancy firm in here today talking to one of my advisers and raising these sorts of issues and raising the point that your government bureaucracy and the minister's office—not just your office, but the Treasurer's office—do not have any idea about the details of the provisions that were announced last Tuesday.
—Are you saying that the tax commissioner is wrong?

—You have to provide the precise details by 3.15 p.m. today, and you have failed to do that. Yesterday in question time, Senator Short, you were asked five or six questions relating to the outcome
of the Premiers Conference. The first question related to this sales tax issue. In yesterday's
Hansard
on page 1582, Senator Short, in answer to a question relating to sales tax applying to privately plated vehicles, you said:

speech.para: As from 11 June 1996, where those vehicles are wholly or partly included in the remuneration package of the employee. That is quite clear. It has been clearly stated in the outcome of the conference.

The critical issue is the original announcement, the original intention and the original date on which the announcement was made, which was last Tuesday, 11 June. You reaffirmed this yesterday, Senator Short, in one of your very few answers to questions we asked yesterday. If we look through them, we are not surprised that this government has been incompetent. We are not surprised that you have acted illegally when we look at the answers you fail to give to questions.
(Time expired)

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —I find it absolutely bizarre, as I said yesterday, that we have the taxpayers' friends over there who stand up every day after question time and tell us that they have become the taxpayers' friends. These are the blokes who have put tax up by billions upon billions of dollars in the last four years, who have added deficit after deficit after four years of recovery, as Senator Hill says, who have implemented a whole range of new wholesale sales taxes and who have implemented a whole range of taxes on petrol and wine.
—But you have done it illegally.

—And here is Senator Sherry, the acting tax commissioner, this trumped up former union secretary, who comes in here and now pretends that he knows his job better than the tax commissioner. Senator Short has already given you today, Senator Sherry—through you, Madam Deputy President—the advice of the tax commissioner.

break.para: The fact of the matter is that opposition senators started off trying to have a debate about the economy but realised it was not very good ground. Senator Bob Collins said to Senator Short today that he had a very good story, and he suggested that Senator Short put it better. It is a very good story to tell about the economy. talk.start.para: —What did the state premiers say, Ian?

—We have seen that the state premiers have been prepared to come together with Prime Minister Howard and Treasurer Costello to make a significant commitment on behalf of the states, including Tasmania, Senator Murphy, to ensure that future generations of Australians do not have to pay the high mortgage that you people have imposed upon them through your fiscal ineptitude.

break.para: The other interesting fact is that the government has sought to overcome what has become a serious rort in the taxation system in Australia. Of course, the Commonwealth did not get everything it wanted to. The states, as I said yesterday, do not come along to Canberra and say, `Here's a few billion dollars; we want to sort out the tax system. Take all the money; we'll pay our share.' The reason this opposition is so nervous about sorting out the sales tax rort—the reason that particularly Senator Murphy, another former union activist, is so embarrassed about sorting out the sales tax rort—is their continued embarrassment over my uncovering a few years ago the old Transport Workers Union sales tax rort. That involved a quarter of a million dollars worth of sales tax. I first raised the issue in January 1994.

When they were in government, Labor leased luxury cars like Fairmonts—that is probably what Senator Murphy drives these days—to their mates in the Transport Workers Union. It is the same sales tax rort. This is why they are so embarrassed about it. They do not want to talk about the sales tax rorts because they leased cars to their mates in the Transport Workers Union—a tax free, quarter of a million dollar gift to your mates in the union.
Here we are having to fix up the rort. The Treasurer in his statement of 14 June—for Senator Sherry, who cannot even get his calendar right—said:

Wholesale sales tax will apply to general purpose road vehicles provided wholly or partly for private use as part of remuneration by Commonwealth, State, Territory and local governments to take effect from 11 June . . .
The other issue that we need to pin down is the fallacy about taxpayers' friends.

talk.start.para: —Friends?

—These people were so friendly to the taxpayers. They had 13 years in government to be the taxpayers' friends. What did they do? They were so friendly that they said, `We love you so much that we are going to smother you with more taxes because you love them.'

break.para: These are the taxpayers' friends. They have come in here with this trumped up thing saying we did not put an ad in Mr Packer's and Mr Murdoch's newspapers by 3 o'clock today—even though they are three days out—because we want to let all the taxpayers know about this.

Who are the taxpayers who are affected? They are the Commonwealth government—that is us. We had better put an ad in the paper and tell ourselves about the new tax arrangements. They are the state governments, who were actually at the conference. We had better put an ad in the newspapers and tell Mr Court and Mr Carr that there are some more taxes. We had better put an ad in the paper and tell local government.

There are three tiers of government affected by this. You are coming in here and saying that we have got the time wrong and we put
ads in the paper. Try harder next time. What a joke you guys are!
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —It is extremely disturbing to hear anybody in the Senate suggest that words of legislation are a joke. If the implication is that it depends on who you need to inform as to whether or not the law and the words of the law need to be complied with, then that is a real problem in relation to contempt of the parliamentary and democratic process. Basically, it is not a selective law, you cannot decide whether or not you think it is a good tax. It has nothing to do with whether it is a good tax or a bad tax.

speech.para: Many of us think that the way in which it was put together was probably not very wise. However, the idea is also not about who the people are who are interested in the outcomes of the tax. It is not a selective bill that says that you can choose who you inform. Section 130B of the Sales Tax Assessment Act clearly says:
Where a Minister makes a public statement which announces that it is the intention of the Government to introduce into a House of the Parliament a bill . . .

The reality is that there will always be groups in our society who will want to change the decision of a government. We do agree that the states have a greater lobbying ability, obviously, than most other groups in the community. However, in this case they acted as lobbyists. The fact that this was a meeting with an obviously very influential group of people—albeit state government lobbyists and premiers—is not sufficient to say that the announcement did not take place. The announcement did take place. The very influential lobbyists, that is, the state premiers, had a difference of opinion.

There is nothing in the act which indicates that it depends on whether the announcement is to be presented to an influential group of lobbyists or not. That is not in there. There is nothing in it which says anything about whether it affects people in government or in government positions.

para.break: If we are to have respect for the parliamentary process, perhaps the government needs to speak to its departments and com municate. I am sure that there must have been somebody within one of the departments trying to present this concern to the minister, saying that this was the statutory requirement. If this communication did not happen, then one wonders on how many other occasions communication between departments and the minister may be so bad that the opportunity for ministers to fulfil their statutory requirements is not met.

speech.para: To base a defence on whether or not a group, albeit a very influential group, agreed with this announcement is not a defence relating to this government abiding by its statutory requirements. Therefore, I rise to support what has been stated here today by the opposition.

Of course we rise to support it, because it was, in fact, the amendment of the Greens (WA) in the fist place. We believe that the community did have the right to know about the implications for taxation, especially such things as sales tax. A government press release is not good enough. People in the community do have the right to know. They have the right to know when a change has occurred. They do have the right to know in simple terms what the implications of this change are.

Even government employees have the right to know. Of course, the implications of these changes not only affect government employees but also the revenue and services provided to all states and territories in Australia. That has become quite clear. The arguments that have been put by the government in this case are not sufficient. I believe that they have to admit before this Senate that they have made an error. They have to work out a way of purging that error to this place and to the democracy of Australia.

petition.title: Industrial Relations
petition.para: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that any reform to Australia's system of industrial relations should recognise the special needs of employees to be protected from disadvantage, exploitation and discrimination in the workplace.

We the petitioners oppose the Coalition policies which represent a fundamentally anti‐worker regime and we call upon the Senate to provide an effective check and balance to the Coalition's legislation program by rejecting such a program and ensuring that:
(1) The existing powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) be maintained to provide for an effective independent umpire overseeing awards and workplace bargaining processes.

(2) The proposed system of Australian Workplace Agreements (A Was) should be subject to the same system of approval required for the approval of certified agreements (through enterprise bargaining). Specifically an A WA should not come into effect unless it is approved by the AIRC.

(3) The approval of agreements contained in the legislation should be public and open to scrutiny. There should be provision for the involvement of parties who have a material concern relating to the approval for an agreement, including unions seeking to maintain the no disadvantage guarantees.
(4) Paid rates awards be preserved and capable of adjustment, as is currently the case in the legislation.
(5) The AIRC's powers to arbitrate and make awards must be preserved in the existing form and not be restricted to a stripped back set of minimum or core conditions.
(6) The legislation should encourage the process of collective bargaining and ensure that a certified agreement within its term of operation cannot be over‐ridden by a subsequent A WA.
(7) The secondary boycott provisions should be preserved in their existing form.

(8) The powers and responsibility of the AIRC to ensure the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be preserved in its existing form. We oppose any attempt by the Coalition to restrict the AIRC from dealing with over‐award gender based pay equity issues.
(9) A `fair to all round' for unfair dismissal so that all workers currently able to access these remedies are able to do so in a fair manner, at no cost.
(10) Workers under State industrial legislation maintain their rights to access the federal awards system in its current form.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to reject the above proposed reforms to the area of industrial relations.

interject.speaker: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —The President has received a letter from Senator Chamarette proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

interject.para: The government's continued commitment to unsustainable logging practices as demonstrated by the national forest policy statement and the export control regulations tabled in the Senate on 30 April 1996, and as evidenced by the decision of the Dutch government not to buy Western Australian karri timber for canal liners on the grounds that it is being logged unsustainably.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places
—

speech.speaker: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

talk.start.para: —The national forest policy, by virtue of its lack of real initiatives to get logging out of native forests or to ensure secure preservation of high conservation value forests is a blueprint for unsustainable logging practices. The national forest policy statement proposed getting export woodchipping out of native forests by the year 2000. This government is showing a commitment to doing exactly the opposite by having no commitment to a reduction in the yearly woodchip quota.

speech.para: In fact, there is great concern throughout the community that this government is about to raise the ceiling on the woodchip quotas and declare open slather on our nation's unprotected forest heritage. In relation to this matter, Dr Bob Brown said:
. . . our wild forests will be fed at an unprecedented rate into the rubbish tips of the northern hemisphere.
In relation to the government's Natural Heritage Trust announcement, he said:
It makes the Natural Heritage Trust repair ethic look like applying bandaids to the hand that holds the chainsaw.
In his usual colourful language, he has hit the nail on the head.

break.para: Four years after the drafting of this national forest policy statement, we still do not have a single hectare more of old growth forests in secure conservation reserves. We have many precious areas proposed for protection, yet all of this is teetering on the outcome of fickle political will. Meanwhile the chainsaws are continuing in the south‐west of Western Australia, the north of New South Wales, East Gippsland and Tasmania. This government will not even give a commitment to protecting areas already identified as having outstanding natural values by the Australian Heritage Commission's register of the national estate in the south‐west of Western Australia.

Against this alarming backdrop comes a signal of hope. International governments are now echoing what countless scientific studies from the Barnett report in Western Australia to the Resource Assessment Commission's timber inquiry at a national level have told us, that logging old growth native forests is not sustainable. It is not possible to simply regrow an old growth forest ecosystem that has taken thousands of years to develop and is a delicate and extraordinarily complex self‐sustaining system. Once you have destroyed it, it is gone. Plantations regrow; forests do not. They certainly cannot be replaced by the monoculture, even‐aged, simplified forest plantations we put in their place and call regeneration or regrowth.

The Greens have no objections whatsoever to plantation timbers being used. To use plantation timbers is ecologically sustainable; to have agroforestry is ecologically sustainable. We should be planting more trees on already cleared lands. We should be preventing further land clearance for agricultural or any other purposes. We ought to be utilising those resources so that the timber industry can have an ecologically sustainable base. It is not possible to do that if we are clearing old growth forests in the guise of setting up plantations.

Instead of looking at that plantation based industry on cleared land, forests that are hundreds of years old are being progressively juvenilised. They have been simplified, stripped of undergrowth and the moss covered fallen logs essential to survival of so many
rare and endangered species. These new regrowth forests or monocultures are lacking in old trees with hollows for small marsupials, lacking tree ferns, lichens, vines and all the wonderful biodiversity for which old growth forests are the pool. Instead, under the national forest policy statement we are turning our forests into tree farms; uniform, static, lifeless wood factories where few animals move, few birds call, streams become dry and the soil infertile.

We know also from a hard economic perspective that these forests will never reach the yield of plantations and agroforestry on already cleared land. In Western Australia plantations yield three times that of regenerated forest, whilst agroforestry can yield as much as 10 times as much. In this situation they also fulfil the essential secondary purpose of lowering the water table and reducing the crippling salinity affecting our farmlands. Still the national forest policy keeps us bound to native forests, bound to continued species and habitat extinction and bound to economic loss under enormous subsidisation of a timber industry that cannot keep itself afloat and sheds more and more rural jobs every day.

On 22 May this year the Western Australian Conservation Council received a letter from the Dutch Ministry of Transport, Public Works and Water Management indicating its decision not to buy karri from primary, that is, old growth, forest. Their intention was to buy karri from the south‐west of Western Australia for canal linings in the Netherlands. After an extensive period of assessment and investigation between the government of The Netherlands and the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management, the Dutch came to the conclusion that to import karri from the south‐west of Western Australia would be to exploit an unsustainable resource.

This decision is of the utmost significance. It will set a precedent not only for the Netherlands but for the European Community and the world. The Dutch are world leaders in environmental standards. It stands to reason that if they will not buy karri, no‐one else with environmental and ethical concerns will either. As I said before, that is a most hopeful
thing that has happened. The people in Western Australia who know that our beautiful karri and marri forests are unique in all the world and who see their destruction with grave concern and feel totally powerless have at least gained some vindication from overseas. It is an international view of what we are doing to our precious old growth forests.

The Dutch government decided it would only buy karri from existing areas of sustainably managed production forests. Their definition of `sustainable' is much more extensive and sensible than ours. It includes monitoring for biodiversity, the necessity for and extent of buffer zones, the extent of forest diseases, the amount of prescribed burning and implications for climate change.

The karri which did come from appropriate regional regrowth plantations was too small to fulfil their requirements. The WA forestry practices failed miserably in other ways. When the conservation and land management departments management plans are based on those of interstate authorities and vice versa, this also has clear implications for forest management nationally. With Australia's recent record on the environment we are looking at becoming outsiders in a global community already committed to drastic action against the ecological collapse imminent on this planet. Affluence such as ours relative to that of developing countries means that there is no excuse for continued destruction of our very life support systems.

We have the technology and the ability to create a sustainable wood products industry. We do not need to clear our forests to service a foreign debt of 50 per cent of GDP, or to scratch out a meagre existence with unsustainable farming practices, or to get fuel for basic cooking or hygiene, or to raise cash crops. To continue to devastate our last remaining native forests as per the national forest policy is to continue an ecological violation of not just domestic but international proportions.

The Dutch decision holds some grave messages for the future of the forest industry in Australia. Either log forests sustainably on farmland and leave the old-growth forests alone or risk a crippled timber industry in both domestic and international markets. This
is not the assertion merely of an impassioned conservationist community or the majority of Australians—even though it is that—but it is of hard economic reality direct from the global community. That is why it is of vital importance on a day when this government is considering its actions in relation to woodchip export licences.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This MPI debate has been brought to the Senate by the Greens (WA).
