That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

speech.speaker: Kemp, Sen Rod

talker.name: Senator KEMP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That these bills be now read a second time.

I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in
Hansard
Leave granted.
MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1996

The bill and the associated Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1996 are part of the Commonwealth's response to the horrific events at Port Arthur. This tragedy has concentrated attention on the fact that there are large holdings of types of rapid‐fire weapons in our community which are simply not justifiable in the overall national interest.

All Australian Governments are acting swiftly on tighter gun control, a significant element of which is a twelve month amnesty and compensation scheme. This scheme, likely to begin formally on 1 July, will require gun owners to hand in those guns to be the subject of nation‐wide bans in return for fair and proper compensation. This covers all self‐loading rifles, self‐loading shotguns and pump‐action shotguns, whether licensed or unlicensed, subject to very narrow exceptions.

Through a one‐off increase of 0.2% in the Medicare levy, these bills will raise the necessary funds to re‐imburse states and territories for the direct cost of payments they will have made to relevant gun owners.

I am reluctant at any time to add to the financial burden of Australians. But this bill imposes a special one year impost which I think most Australians will regard as necessary in the circumstances. Through contributing an amount estimated to cost someone on average weekly earnings a total of around $70 or $1.40 a week, Australians can assist
in the greatest reduction of firearms ever contemplated in this or most other countries.

A very large total cost is involved. The estimate is that the increase in levy will raise around $500 million. The Commonwealth judges it to be in the national interest to offer assistance on such a scale to the states and territories, notwithstanding that gun control falls largely within their responsibilities. National leadership needs to be exercised so that the problem of the proliferation of these guns is confronted swiftly and adequately.

The terms of the `buy back' scheme will be subject to national agreement and I have made it clear to Premiers and Chief Ministers that funding by the Commonwealth is based on the strong agreement of all states and territories to implement the measures agreed at the meeting of Police Ministers on 10 May.

I note that a recent University of Canberra study supports the Government's conclusion that an increase in the Medicare levy for this purpose is the most desirable of several options, including on equity and efficiency grounds.

The rate of Medicare levy will be raised from 1.5 per cent to 1.7 per cent for the 1996‐97 income year only. The terms of the bill ensure that the rate will be returned to the present level of 1.5 per cent for the 1997‐98 and subsequent income years.

The bill will allow imposition of a proportion of the full Medicare levy, equivalent to a rate of 0.2%, on members of the Defence Forces, and in some circumstances members of their household, who are currently exempt from the Medicare levy. Again, this will be just for the duration of the 1996‐97 income year. The same income thresholds, reduced levy and phasing‐in arrangements applying to other taxpayers will apply.
This measure puts Defence personnel in the same position as other Australians required to meet this special community‐wide impost.

The figure of $500 million represents the best advice about the cost states and territories could face in meeting the direct cost of `buy back' arrangements. Any surplus will be returned to taxpayers through the Medicare levy system.

Details of the national amnesty and `buy back' scheme are being worked on by a working party of senior Commonwealth and state officials. The clear objective is to offer incentives which secure a significant return of firearms as expeditiously as possible. This includes a regime of fair and proper compensation, with values set by people with appropriate expertise. It also includes significant penalties for those who fail to return banned weapons at the expiration of twelve months, with more serious penalties applying in respect of high fire‐power weapons.

I understand that the thinking at this stage is that the scheme of compensation will involve a schedule of values for particular categories of firearm, depending on condition. Such values would be set by a national panel which includes government and gun industry representation, and independent valuation expertise.

I am gratified by the response of most Australians to the leadership shown by all Governments on gun control. Many will be inconvenienced by this and other elements of the gun control package. It is a matter of honest regret that taxpayers need to meet this cost, and that law‐abiding gun owners need to surrender guns which they have found useful to them in one way or another.

The rural community in particular are likely to feel the brunt of tighter restrictions, though primary producers will be able to use smaller magazine, low powered semi‐automatics where there is a demonstrable occupational need which cannot be met by other means. My experience of this community gives me every confidence that they will shoulder responsibly the burden that the new state gun laws will impose.

I do not enjoy imposing this degree of regulation and inconvenience, which reaches into many Australian homes. But when the whole of the matter is weighed, there is a greater good to be served in taking such comprehensive measures.

The profound national trauma which followed the gun violence at Port Arthur has caused us to ask fundamental questions about what sort of firearms are acceptable in our community. Logic, not emotion, has carried all governments collectively to a conclusion that the availability of semi‐automatic rifles and shotguns should be severely circumscribed, and that there should be greater rigour generally in gun licensing and registration systems.
All of us with public duties in this matter need to fully implement the agreement reached by Police Ministers, and to keep our compact with the Australian people.
These historic measures are designed to avoid any slide into a `gun culture' in this country. We must build a better and safer community for the future.
I commend the bill to honourable senators. I table the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1996

The bill makes consequential amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 in relation to the payment of a proportion of the full Medicare levy, equivalent to a rate of 0.2%, by Defence personnel and their relatives or associates who are currently exempt from the Medicare levy. This allows such persons to be subject to the community‐wide
impost which is designed to raise funds to re‐imburse states and territories for payments made under the gun `buy back' scheme.
I commend the bill to honourable senators. I table the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

debate.title: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

debate.sub1.title: Report of Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

speech.speaker: Calvert, Sen Paul

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Crane, I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996, together with submissions and the transcript of proceedings.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

proctext.para: Consideration resumed from 17 June.

talk.start.para: —The committee is considering the Housing Assistance Bill 1996. The bill has been taken as a whole. On behalf of the Greens (WA), Senator Margetts has moved amendment No. 3:

para.tab: Many people have difficulty obtaining housing that is environmentally appropriate. Adequate insulation and design to minimise water and energy consumption without compromising amenity is not generally required or provided. Urban planning often does not take the need to reduce mechanised transport or to optimise passive solar exposure into consideration.

People who are economically or socially disadvantaged may be less likely to obtain environmentally appropriate housing. This can have adverse economic effects. They may also have difficulty obtaining housing in areas that maximise their income through proximity to required services, adequate public transport, employment, shopping and areas for social interaction and support.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para:
—I want to put briefly on record that, at the time we adjourned last night, I
was speaking to my amendment No. 3. I ran out of time in outlining the issues associated with the amendment. I want to make it clear that what I was presenting was not—I repeat not—a second reading speech. It was in fact an explanation of the issues behind the amendments which I was putting.

speech.para: The trouble with those amendments and the trouble with the issues we are dealing with is that there are many people in the community who are having trouble finding the connections between things like public transport, energy and housing. We have had those same answers again and again from public servants and representatives of departments who are dealing with these issues, who have taken a long, long time to see those connections.

Transport is the major issue that we are talking about. Basically, if you assume that issues of transport, energy, the environment and housing are separate, then we will never get to a policy which deals with those issues. That is the reason for what I was doing, and that is what I will be continuing to do as I put my amendments on this very important bill.

talker.name: Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para:
—The government is not prepared to support this amendment. I think that there are matters in here which are addressed elsewhere in the preamble and we think that the issues raised are adequately addressed by amendment No. 4, which we agreed to.
(Quorum formed)
—Senator Faulkner, are you going to respond on behalf of the government?

speech.speaker: Faulkner, Sen John

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I would love to if I were in government. I do not want to admit this, but we actually lost the election, Mr Chairman.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para:
4.
Preamble, page 2 (line 6), after "adequate", insert "and ecologically appropriate".

This is a simple, very basic inclusion of the idea that public housing must be ecologically appropriate. We used the word `ecologically' rather than the word `environmentally' to acknowledge some of the broader issues of urban design. Consumption patterns were built in through housing choices rather than limiting consideration to basic energy efficiency and immediately obvious environmental impacts. I understand that there is broad party support for this amendment, and the Greens (WA) welcome that support.

Yesterday I was speaking about the fact that public housing was both an environmental impact in terms of energy use and a social impact. In my remarks I talked about a part of the paragraph I was speaking to; in fact, I was quite explicit. So I will be addressing these types of issues in my amendments; that is, that public housing is often seen to have no connection with insulation or other energy and water conservation practices, with solar hot water heaters or with costs imposed on tenants, including transport costs. I think it is a problem that public housing is seen to have little relation with urban design, car dependency, access to services, import of fuel or other such elements.

I think it is a major problem that people cannot see the contradictions and waste in funding programs and having policies at all levels of government in relation to housing design and urban form and then spending a billion dollars a year on housing, ignoring everything else they are doing or advising. I think it is indicative that we have some good models like the Department of Defence, which is utilising some of the important economic advantages of the things that we have been advocating to defence housing, yet the department of housing cannot even see the connection in relation to public housing. That has been almost unbelievable. I am disappointed that my raising this issue is seen as a problem.

para.break: I have mentioned several factors already when speaking to earlier amendments, but I have a few more comments to make in order to make the connection clear. I would appreciate it if those views could be heard so that I do not need to repeat them in subse quent related amendments. If I can speak to the issues now, I will not bore you for too long. Those who know me know that, in general, I am known as the senator of short speeches, and that is why people rush to the chamber when they know I am getting up to speak. There are exceptions, and that is where the issue is complex and important to the Greens, but I do not just fill in time with political point scoring.

speech.para: In relation to earlier amendments, I mentioned some of the impacts on urban form relating to where we put public housing and about the unfortunate trend to eliminate established public housing in central areas to build new houses on the fringes. This is an important ecological issue and an important social justice issue as well. It is absolutely relevant to all my amendments to both ecological sustainability and to offering choice of housing and location.

The location of public housing is important. I am speaking about the fact that for many people the outer fringes are not well served with public transport. Even when there is some service, it often takes many times longer to travel the same distance by public transport than it would by car. In some areas there are buses that travel only once a day, and that is on weekdays. The public transport falls in a heap on weekends and holidays. It becomes extremely difficult for people to negotiate the long distances from urban fringes without a car.

Moreover, there are few, if any, suburban shops in many of these suburbs. People have to go to town to shop. Taxis will not go there because it is too far and they feel it is not worth their while. Of course, if you are in a public housing area, you are not going to be able to afford to take expensive taxis to go to the shops. There are few medical clinics with facilities as there are, for instance, around Fremantle, and schools and any social entertainment are also at a distance. The social problems of creating welfare ghettos are also well known.

So providing public housing in such areas without considering the urban impact would lock the poor into getting a car, which would usually be an old petrol‐guzzling bomb that
uses leaded petrol, for which the poor will be penalised in fuel tax. For those with less money and for whom driving is difficult, you lock them into isolation which is built of lack of access to health and other services.

There are obviously difficulties in getting to work. So you have this cycle of people being expected to find a job, and it is actually being made difficult for them to choose in relation to access to jobs that are available. They have a lot of difficulty even getting to training courses, to job interviews or to an actual place of work. It is not an impossible situation, but we do make many people's lives far more difficult than there is any need to be.

To add insult to injury, most of the disadvantages that we load such public tenants up with have an economic price tag. So it costs money to be disadvantaged. Think about when you go shopping. If you have to travel long distances, it is quite difficult to do that, even on public transport. If you have to walk or you have no other way to do that, then it is going to make it impossible.

Better cities and urban design criteria generally would indicate that it is better to have public housing more centrally located and that it is important to assure adequate access to shops, work and social outlets. It is important not to create class-based neighbourhoods. It is preferable to have this access based on proximity so that people can walk or ride a bike easily. If not proximity, then it is necessary to assure access through a frequent, extensive, inexpensive, safe all-hours public transport system where travel time is not excessive.

No‐one here would be happier than I if governments, state or federal, said to me, `If there is a trade‐off and we are pushing public housing further out to the fringes of urban areas, then the trade‐off is that we are going to provide the money necessary for good public transport infrastructure, to provide the links between suburbs and not just between suburbs and cities.' No‐one would be happier than I to think that providing funding for those links is a reasonable suggestion. I do not see it at the moment. I see that the emphasis often is on roads and not necessarily on providing access and equity to the people
who are less well off. That is the basis of our amendment and I commend it to the Senate.

speech.speaker: Faulkner, Sen John

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —Yesterday, in debate during the committee stage of this bill, I indicated that I would be listening with interest to Senator Margetts's eloquence in relation to her case for this amendment. I was certainly minded to support the amendment because it inserts in the preamble to the bill a reference to the desirability of ecologically appropriate housing. I made the point earlier in this debate that I felt that this was a better way of achieving this objective in the preamble of the bill than perhaps some of the other amendments that had previously been proposed by Senator Margetts.

speech.para: I certainly want to say that the opposition does believe that it is appropriate and important that housing be ecologically sensitive. It is also important that this be referred to in the bill. I think the issue is best dealt with here in the part of the bill which explicitly recognises the adverse effects of the inability to obtain appropriate—including ecologically appropriate—housing.

In indicating that the opposition will support amendment No. 4, we will also, obviously, support the corresponding amendment to clause 4 where the aims of the bill are set out—I believe in amendment No. 13 that stands in the name of Senator Margetts.

speech.speaker: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

talk.start.para:
—I would like to add the support of the Democrats for this amendment put forward by Senator Margetts, for many of the reasons outlined by the opposition and earlier by Senator Margetts. I think it is important that the body of the bill is amended accordingly, so I am glad to see that you not only seek to amend the preamble, as originally put forward, but also to amend the bill. I think amendment No. 13 does that as well. Yesterday, when discussing the support of the Democrats for amendment No. 3, which deals with environmentally appropriate housing, I put forward the idea that environmental standards should be better incorporated into public housing. That is a longstanding part of
Democrat policy. I think that is worth reiterating.

speech.para: We recognise that there is a need to ensure environmentally sound outcomes for public housing tenants. Included in that we have referred to waste recycling, insulation, retrofitting and so on. I would seek an assurance during this debate from the minister that in the renegotiation of the Commonwealth‐state housing agreement we see some discussion of the environmental design of housing. I note that this is consistent with page 20 of the coalition's policy on housing which refers to better forms of urban design. I understand that there was something similar to that in the earlier draft of this bill. I think it seeks to be re‐inserted in the bill in the form of the opposition's amendment, which we will also be supporting.

speech.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talker.name: Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —As I already indicated in my response to the third amendment, the government is prepared to accept this amendment. It is consistent with our party's policy. A number of the issues which were raised by Senator Margetts in her comments are ones which I would identify, including the need to protect disadvantaged people as much as is humanly possible from the greater costs of being disadvantaged. The problems with ghettos of disadvantaged people, particularly on the fringes of cities, are an issue which I have long been concerned about myself. So she touched a chord with what she had to say on those matters. We are happy to accept the fourth amendment.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para:
5.
Preamble, page 3 (line 8), omit "offer", substitute "ensure".

This amendment is really connected to our amendment No. 6. I understand the opposition is willing to support our amendment No. 6 but not No. 5. I am sure Senator Faulkner will elucidate that. This amendment is simply about strengthening the language of this clause. I would like to see choice ensured, especially the sort of choice that I envisage in
my next amendment. I also believe that it is all too easy to offer choices that are not really functional choices. Something like the keystart program is not really a choice for many people, requiring, as it does, the promise of reasonable income and the ability to take on a standard loan. They still have the same amount to pay back but they end up getting it at a later time.

In fact, I have concerns with the way most of the genuine home ownership subsidy programs disappeared or were phased out around 1986‐87 and were replaced by schemes which allowed a number of home buyers to appear to get assistance while actually building up a deferred debt—this sounds a bit like students! This quickly landed a number of them in trouble when house values declined and their total debt mounted. They found that if they sold their house and tried to get out, they owed Homeswest between $15,000 and $20,000. I understand other states had similar problems and in most cases debt was written off. Low income people were allowed to escape from this diabolical scheme.

I feel that offering choice in this context often comes down to three options—you can go on the rental waiting list and wait seven years, you can go on the purchase waiting list under the scheme and wait five years or you can go on key‐start. If you are about to graduate from uni and have a job waiting, you can get a house in six to nine months. To me that is not a choice; it is a system that discriminates and differentiates on the basis of income or probable future income.

It often comes down to no choice at all. Some people have to struggle on, while the funding is given to those who are nearly able to afford to buy a house under normal conditions. I believe a requirement to ensure choice may be seen as a requirement to ensure that there are various programs functionally accessible to each client. It is in this sense that I wish to amend the bill.

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para:
—The opposition will not be supporting amendment No. 5, as proposed by Senator Margetts. This part of the bill deals with the
intention of the parliament in relation to housing assistance. I do not believe that it is appropriate to alter the language of this part of the bill to imply that housing assistance in and of itself can ensure anything. I believe that that is the role of the parties to the agreement. The opposition, as I have indicated, will not be support the amendment.
—The Democrats will not be supporting this amendment.

speech.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talker.name: Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —Nor will the government.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para:
6.
Preamble, page 3 (line 10), after "assistance", insert "and between different types of housing and between different areas in which housing is located".

Amendment No. 6 was designed to ensure that the preamble includes a fairly specific reference to choice of where to live. It is designed to assure that there is housing available in most areas and not just in the fringe areas or welfare ghettoes. It is also designed to indicate that choice should be offered between different types of housing, including flats, separate houses, community housing and so on. It should not be, `You can live in these state housing blocks or else you can have a house out in Woop Woop.' There should be diversity of housing. It should be available in most areas. This was something the better cities program had begun to implement with a bit of diversity in public housing planned for inner city areas like East Perth.

Basically, what we are saying here is that it is important that there is choice. It is also important, as I mentioned before, that you do not have a system in which the places where people want to live—the places where you can get access to services and public transport, which is often what people on the least incomes need—are unavailable.

It is reasonable, I would say, to have some trade-off. It is reasonable that public housing in more valuable urban areas may be of a
different nature. You cannot expect to have the same level of garden. You cannot expect to necessarily have the same space between you and the fence. But those kind of choices mean that you make appropriate housing choices—group housing, community housing and medium density housing.

I want to praise the previous housing minister in Western Australia, Jim McGinty. I must say that there is not a lot I used to praise Jim McGinty for. But to give credit where credit is due, he did make a real effort to make sure that there was funded public housing in areas like Fremantle and East Perth, areas which have good accessibility to public transport services, hospitals and so on. This housing was designed in ways that people could look at it and say, `That is good use of the land. There is good space built into there. They are not just dog boxes and they are actually built with people in mind.' I think we can do that. Often it does not cost more to design things well and I think those choices should be available.

speech.speaker: Faulkner, Sen John

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —As Senator Margetts has indicated, this amendment inserts a reference to the need to take account of location and housing type when providing housing assistance. I believe that the location of housing—especially in relation to transport, work opportunities, access to services and support networks, and the like—and the type of housing, such as flats, houses, townhouses or whatever, are critically important to people and can make a significant difference to the quality of life that they experience.

speech.para: The importance people attach to these aspects of housing should be reflected in this legislation. This amendment achieves that. It is for that reason the opposition will support the amendment and also the corresponding amendment to clause four where the aims of the bill are set out. I believe that is amendment No. 12, standing in the name of Senator Margetts.

speech.speaker: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

talk.start.para:
—The Democrats will also support this amendment. We consider it an important one. Again, I am glad to see that
we are seeking to amend not only the preamble to reflect these considerations but also the body of the act. We will also be supporting amendment No. 12. The Democrats have long believed that the Commonwealth‐state housing agreement should look at the geographical location issues as well as housing choice issues, perhaps not in a prescriptive way but at least in some form that allows policy delivery performance to be assessed.

speech.para: We recognise that some states have made great advances in trying to avoid the public housing ghettos of the past, and we encourage this. It should be encouraged. As I said in my speech at the second reading stage, massive funding cuts to public housing are not going to help, but nor will a refusal to discuss issues such as housing choice. We certainly support this amendment and commend it to the chamber.

speech.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talker.name: Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —The government's intention in proceeding down the reform path is in fact to give greater choice to tenants, right across the board. We believe that flexibility and choice are not there currently. Under reform, we have the potential to increase that flexibility and choice for tenants. Therefore, we are prepared to accept the amendment Senator Margetts has before the chamber at the moment.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para:
7.
Preamble, page 3 (after line 16), after paragraph (h), insert:

para.tab:
; and (ha)
housing assistance will be provided in ways that ensure that people are offered a choice of housing in most areas, that ensures location of housing reflects the demand within various suburbs, and does not geographically marginalise recipients of assistance either by locale of available housing or through price mechanisms; and

tab.tab:
(hb)
housing assistance will be provided in ways that reflect the need to take environmental costs into account, and to reduce operating
costs to tenants or purchasers through minimum standards of insulation, provision of renewable hot‐water systems, provision of energy‐efficient heating, and other conservation measures.

speech.para:
8.
Preamble, page 3 (line 22), after "housing", insert ", environmentally designed to minimise human impacts on the ecology, and to conserve energy and water wherever possible,".

9.
Preamble, page 3 (line 25), after "housing", insert ", while ensuring that appropriate and affordable housing is available through public provision of housing".

11.
Preamble, page 4 (line 4), after "contribute to", insert "ecological sustainability, the National Greenhouse Response Strategy, and ".

Aside from the environmental impact of urban design, there are social impacts. Cities where people can walk or cycle to most destinations and where there is easy, cheap and reliable public transport for longer distances have many amenity advantages. It is more pleasant, it is more convivial and it is more social. It is safer, since a major factor in reducing crime is an environment where people are on the street in neighbourhoods where they relate to others on a regular, face‐to‐face basis. That is what neighbourhoods were about before we lost them to cars, faceless crowds and shopping districts.

The demographic tendency today is for inner city areas to become gentrified as their advantages are recognised. The lower income people are pushed to the urban fringes or isolated in welfare ghettos. They are often state housing ghettos. We have seen a number of state housing apartments bulldozed in Fremantle, North Fremantle and East Fremantle, although they were fairly well integrated into other housing. Tenants in North Fremantle, mostly older people, were moved out. We have seen the rise of new Homeswest areas on the urban fringes of other less desirable areas such as Medina. Of course, areas like Balga in Western Australia remain important state housing suburbs.

The Greens have supported plans occasionally floated to put more public housing in inner city areas and to see more diversity in where housing is provided. That is what we are attempting to include—people being offered a choice of housing in most areas. So
we are strengthening our concerns here, wishing to do such things as minimise human impacts on the ecology and ensure that appropriate and affordable housing is available through the public provision of housing.

In amendment No. 11, the Greens are asking that the programs contribute to ecological sustainability and the national greenhouse response strategy. It would seem to be obvious that if you have a housing program and some kind of commitment to the greenhouse response strategy, you actually use that. If you accept that ecological sustainability is part of how housing programs should operate, then it is very appropriate that such things as the national greenhouse strategy be part of the way you handle them. This is what we are doing with these amendments. We are being specific and setting out the kinds of things that should be quite achievable. They should be integrated into programs such as housing. I commend our amendments to the chamber.

speech.speaker: Faulkner, Sen John

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —In relation to amendment No. 7, I have indicated that I do agree that locational issues are important, but I believe the previous amendment does effectively deal with that particular matter. That matter will be dealt with again, I expect, under the aims of the bill. As far as amendment Nos 8 and 11 are concerned, I do believe the amendment we have dealt with in relation to ecologically appropriate housing is quite adequate to deal with the substantive issues Senator Margetts envisages here in those three amendments, as well as in relation to amendment No. 9.

speech.para:
In relation to amendment No. 9, this part of the preamble of the bill deals with those who might be parties in the provision of housing assistance, where private sector involvement is encouraged. The private sector does have a legitimate role to play in the provision of housing. It can complement the provision of housing by other parties. I do not believe it is appropriate to insert the phrase proposed by Senator Margetts, which I think could be misconstrued as effectively limiting the role of the private sector to that of a subsidiary, rather than a complement. It is for all those
reasons that the opposition will be opposing amendment Nos 7, 8, 9 and 11.

speech.speaker: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

talk.start.para: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I have to seek your guidance on this because the Democrats will be supporting amendment Nos 7, 9 and 11 but not amendment No. 8. I suspect that I should have requested that the amendments be split. Is that the case?
—The chair will be putting the question in relation to those three amendments, and the final amendment will be dealt with separately.

—Thank you for that advice. This is my first committee stage, so I am still working through it. As I indicated, the Australian Democrats will support amendment Nos 7 and 9 for reasons outlined earlier. My concern with amendment No. 8 is that it is somewhat prescriptive and perhaps ventures into overkill. I apologise to Senator Margetts, but the Democrats will not be supporting amendment No. 8.

speech.para: In regard to amendment No. 11, the contribution of housing—particularly heating costs—to the greenhouse gas problem is significant. Energy efficiency should be considered an essential part of housing policy. For that reason, the Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment.

talker.name: Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —The government is not prepared to accept any of these amendments, largely for the sorts of reasons that the opposition has already put on the record.
—The question is that amendment Nos 7, 9 and 11 be agreed to.
—The question is that amendment No. 8 be agreed to.

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I move:

break.para:
1.
Preamble, page 3 (line 23), after "bodies", insert ", as appropriate, in view of the regulatory and other functions of those bodies with respect to the design, planning and management of cities and towns".

This is an amendment to reinstate reference to the design, planning and management of cities and towns role of local governing bodies. These words were in the original version of the Housing Assistance Bill when it was introduced by the former Labor government in the last session of parliament. When this bill was considered in the House of Representatives, the government refused to reinstate these words. I do not believe that Mr Ruddock, the minister representing the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) in that chamber, gave any satisfactory explanation for the position of the government. He simply said:

The government does not accept the amendment. It will be opposed. We do not believe it is necessary. We do not believe that it achieves an objective, as I outlined in my response to the second reading debate. Our policy does deal with these matters. We do not think it is necessary to include this particular measure in the bill.

That is hardly a brilliant development of substantive arguments on this particular issue. I felt that Mr Ruddock's response to the second reading debate was hardly adequate; indeed, I felt he may not have even actually understood the amendment. He said:

The proposal is unnecessary, and will not of itself achieve anything. Lack of such working does not mean that the funds cannot be used for such purposes, not does it represent a lack of interest on the part of this government in the role of local government in such areas.

This amendment deals with the part of the bill which recognises the desirability of the parties to agreements made under this bill to work cooperatively with local governing bodies. We agree that cooperation is desirable. This is essentially legislation drafted by the previous Labor administration, and we accept that cooperation is necessary. We are concerned to make it clear that when the parties work cooperatively with local governing bodies, they are cognisant of the design, planning and management of cities and towns roles of those local governing bodies.

Before the election, I remind you, Mr Temporary Chairman, and the Senate, that the coalition issued a complete policy on these particular matters. I think it was called the Liberal and National parties' housing and urban design policy. We in the Labor Party thought that was an indication that the coalition did take these matters seriously. The policy says that a future coalition government will commit all Commonwealth projects and departments to achieving high quality design standards for urban and regional planning design; will formulate quality guidelines for Commonwealth funded projects which ensure measurable community benefit; and, will work with the states, territories and local governments, together with the various interested professional organisations, to advance and assess the results of urban and regional design.

I believe the government is not likely to support this amendment. If that is the case, I would see its refusal to reinstate these words as really a backdoor assault, if you like, on the better cities program. That was a program which was premised on an understanding that housing was not just about physical structures; that it made sense, when building houses, to pay attention to people's needs for access to job opportunities, transport, community services, amenities and the like.

I think that the better cities program was a very successful program. The former Labor government takes great pride in the achievements of the better cities program. I believe this amendment that have I proposed to the Senate is worthy of support from the government—if not the government, then certainly the minor parties in the chamber. I commend this amendment to the Senate.

speech.speaker: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

talk.start.para:
—The Australian Democrats support Senator Faulkner's amendment, which seeks to reinsert into the preamble a clause that we consider to be an important one, one that was in the previous government's bill but that has been deleted by this government. I do not believe it is the role of this government to revisit or change the terms of agreements. The states, public housing tenants and community housing organisations were all aware of the
terms of the old bill. That was the basis on which the Commonwealth and the states were discussing the next Commonwealth-state housing agreement in January and December. I believe the government should honour the commitments made by the previous government, just as it should honour its own election commitments in regard to housing.

speech.para: The Democrats consider this issue—the idea that housing policy should take into account the design, planning and management of cities—an important issue. I think it is important that we avoid the growth in ugly public housing ghettos that we saw in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s, and that public housing should be blended into the existing community and the environment. We do not want to see the development of ghettos.
I think this amendment adequately reflects that, recognises this need and places it quite appropriately in the preamble. The Democrats, for that reason, support the reinsertion of this clause.

talk.start.para: —The Greens have been on record, on many occasions, as more than supporting the better cities program. We have always been in there, trying to gee it up and make sure that it achieves its lofty aims. We did not always think it would achieve those, but we do not think that is a reason for throwing the baby out with the bathwater. We do believe it is appropriate that the expectations that communities had in relation to the better cities program be fulfilled. Therefore, we will be supporting the opposition's amendment.

speech.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talker.name: Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —The government's approach to this is one of surprise—surprise that somehow the other parties in this chamber see this as some sort of secret agenda. That would concern me, because it is nothing of the sort.

speech.para:
I was interested to see that Senator Faulkner had, in fact, gone to our election policy. It is acknowledged in the record that we have promised to develop an improved community awareness of urban and regional design issues and opportunities, in association with state governments and representatives of local
government and industry, and to work with the states, territories and local government, together with the various interested professional organisations, to advance and assess the results of the urban and regional design of Australian communities. We do not walk away from that. We do not walk away from it at all.

talk.start.para: —I don't understand why you won't support the amendment.

—Although we do not believe that your amendment enhances the bill in any substantive way, we are not prepared to oppose it on the basis that somehow we have something hidden in the bottom drawer. Therefore, the government will not oppose this amendment.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para:
10.
Preamble, page 3 (line 27), after "including", insert "environmentally oriented groups concerned with conservation, transport and urban form, and".
This amendment is designed to ensure that the list of groups to be consulted is not limited to social justice groups.

In housing, especially, it is important to have some representatives from groups such as environment groups, who often have considerable expertise in conservation and other such issues. I have noted fairly extensively in this debate that in terms of housing—and especially public housing—environmental issues often are, fundamentally, social justice issues.

Questions that I have asked in such things as estimates committees have often been met with, `We do not know whether this is the case,' or `We do not know whether there is an extra cost involved,' and so on, when there have been multitudinous studies done in the areas of housing, housing availability and the social and environmental impact housing has. It has been very disappointing that other information sources have not been involved in the decision making process so far.

When a house is designed, if it would cost the tenant a lot of money each month to live reasonably comfortably, that is a social justice issue. When such a house is rented to the old
or to single parents with young children, the money is not available and, as a consequence, health risks increase, that is a social justice issue. When all the available public housing is out in the outer urban darkness, with little public transport, no government offices, no shopping, no health clinics and no jobs, that is a social justice issue.

There is convergence here. It would be important to consult environmental NGOs even if there were no social justice connections but, in this case, the social justice implications are abundant and important. I commend amendment 10 to the Senate.

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —This amendment recognises the desirability of parties to the agreement working in cooperation with environmentally oriented groups, as specified, along with the other non‐government organisations which are concerned with the provision of housing assistance. I believe that this amendment is one that does have merit. It is for that reason that the opposition will be supporting it.

—The Democrats are also supporting amendment No. 10. We think it is entirely appropriate that, if environmental issues are being discussed as part of Commonwealth‐state housing agreements, the government liaise with those people who understand the issues.

speech.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talker.name: Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —The government does not oppose this amendment.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para:
12.
Clause 4, page 6 (line 10), after "assistance", insert ", between different types of housing and between different areas in which housing is".

What this amendment does is put basic provisions for housing availability into the body of the bill, as aims. We feel that having such a statement in the aims—given the next clause, clause 4(3)—will have the effect of ensuring that it is implemented.

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I indicated earlier that the opposition would support this amendment. Of course, an amendment previously moved by Senator Margetts—I believe it was amenmendment 6—and dealt with and supported by the Senate effectively mirrors this particular amendment to clause 4. As I indicated previously, the opposition will be supporting it.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —There is another word that I would like to place at the end of that amendment, in the interests of clarity and good grammar. That is the word `located'. The amendment will read `in which housing is located'.
—Are you seeking leave, Senator?
—Yes, I seek leave to amend my amendment by inserting the word `located' after the final `is'.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —My amendment now reads:

speech.para:
12.
Clause 4, page 6 (line 10), after "assistance", insert ", between different types of housing and between different areas in which housing is located".

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats support these amendments as well. In the interests of good grammar, we are glad that you amended the amendment. For the reasons we outlined earlier, we will be supporting the amendment. I would like to add that we are glad that you sought to amend the body of the act as well as the preamble to reflect housing choice considerations and ecological concerns.

speech.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talker.name: Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —We are glad that the grammar is going to reflect better on the Senate than it might otherwise have done. We really do not believe that this amendment is necessary. We feel that it was already addressed earlier. However, we do not intend to oppose it.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

13.
Clause 4, page 6 (line 13), after "amenity", insert ", is of ecologically appropriate design".
Amendment No. 13, like amendment No. 12, puts the requirement that housing should be ecologically appropriate into the aims of the act.

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —Like the previous case, this particular amendment mirrors amendments made to the preamble of the bill. As I indicated to the committee earlier, it will be supported by the opposition.

speech.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talker.name: Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —For the same reason I gave in relation to the previous amendment, we do not think there is a need for this amendment, but we do not see the virtue in opposing it either.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para:
14
Clause 4, page 6 (after line 15), after paragraph 4(2)(c), insert:

para.tab:
; and (d)
to ensure that rental housing is available at a cost based on the income of tenants.

speech.para: Amendment No. 14 to clause 4 seeks to ensure that rental housing is available at a cost based on the income of the tenants. This amendment puts in writing the commitment for the government that rentals should relate to the tenant's income rather than just market value. It is a fundamental assurance of availability on terms that do not have large negative impacts on the quality of life. We are seeing a number of people, even in the work force, joining the working poor. It would be unfortunate if more and more people found themselves unable to pay what is necessary for public housing as circumstances change. We believe that the ability to pay should be figured into the cost for public housing.

talker.name: Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para:
—This amendment deals with the issue
of affordability of housing, an area which the Commonwealth is to take full responsibility for through changes to rent assistance. I do not think it is particularly useful as a benchmark for affordability, specifying only that costs should relate to income. I think it would be better to do nothing at all than to introduce a vague and inappropriate benchmark. This is a matter that can be more vigorously pursued when details of the Commonwealth's proposals in relation to rent assistance are on the table. It is for that reason that the opposition will be opposing the amendment.

—The Democrats will be supporting the Greens' amendment No. 14. It reflects in general terms provisions in the housing policies of both the coalition and the Labor Party that tenants in public housing should not pay more than 25 per cent of their income as rent. This amendment before us basically reflects that policy principle. I do not think the government, or the opposition for that matter, should have much difficulty supporting it. On that basis, the Democrats are supporting it.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I wish to add a small point. It is an addition; it is not cutting out any other considerations. It is true that in Australia a growing number of people are spending 40 per cent or more of their incomes on rent. That means that rent related poverty is growing. We certainly know that that is the case amongst students. I believe that other people in our society on low incomes are in a similar situation.

speech.para: Many of our amendments are a model for what we would like to see considered in the future. Consider that we have provided a model. If that model can be bettered at some stage by government or opposition, we are happy to see it. To provide the model, we are saying, `Okay, do better if you can and we are happy to support you if you do it better in the future.'

talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para:

`affordable' appears in clause 1 and again in clause 2. talk.start.para: —I move:

Clause 11, page 11 (after line 22), after subclause (2), insert:

(2A)
During each of the second and third assistance years, the Consolidated Revenue Fund is appropriated in the amount of $1,067,863,000 for the purpose of making grants and other payments under this act.

Labor recognised that the states and territories would need time to reconfigure their housing arrangements to put the reforms announced in
Community and Nation
in place. As the government well understands—I hope it well understands—housing is the sort of business that requires long-term planning; it requires forward planning. We have a

talk.start.para: —The Greens (WA) would like to indicate that we do support the request for the extension to the three‐year period.

speech.speaker: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will also be supporting this request by Senator Faulkner. I think, in light of what Senator Faulkner said about the COAG meeting last week, it was sad, quite unfortunate, that despite pleas and demands by the state Premiers that the Commonwealth actually guarantee that funding would not be cut for state housing and that the specific purpose payments would actually be maintained, no such assurance was given.

speech.para: I made it clear in the second reading debate that the Democrats had some concerns with the previous government's commitment to public housing, although we do believe those commitments, as they were, should be maintained. They were not extreme, just a maintenance of the dollar value of public housing SPPs for three years. speech.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talker.name: Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —I am fascinated to find that the Australian Democrats really do want us to keep our election promises because, no matter how hard we try to keep our election promises, they are doing a dashed good job of preventing us from doing so in other areas. Thanks for your assistance. You might speak to some of your colleagues about other areas of our responsibility.
—I wonder whether she will vote for the Telstra bill.

—Yes, I wonder whether she will. The difficulty is that the parties on the Left, if you like, certainly the parties of the opposition, seem to regard it as mysterious that there is only one year's appropriation of funds in this bill. It is not mysterious. It was very deliberate.

speech.para:
The reason is that we have supported the action which the previous government had been taking in trying to achieve housing reform. We came into government after this had been an agreed position between the state and federal governments for some time. We looked at what had to be done and asked:
why should we delay this, or allow for delay, if it can possibly be moved along? We are not trying to introduce change that has not properly been considered by all parties. We are not trying to stampede people. We are certainly trying to send a signal that we mean serious business, that the reform process which was started by the previous government is a commitment of this government. And we do not want delay.

It does not mean that we do not believe that there has got to be transitional arrangements. But we do not want to send the message that we want to be in the same position in three years time as the one we are in now. So we have said that this is the funding for this year.

In the communique, which the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) has referred to, we have recognised the long lead times for capital funding and the problems of the carryover of funds. We have said that we will give a more detailed statement to the states in August. They will have a better understanding of our proposals when they receive that.

The funding for subsequent years will be by way of annual appropriation. It will be influenced by the stage which the negotiations have reached. We are not going to be providing one sort of funding for one type of housing commitment if a different stage in the negotiation process is reached.

Let me not be misunderstood on this. We are committed to continuing funding for housing. What we are intending to do, as the former government was intending to do, is change the split in who did what. There is nothing mysterious about it. We think it is inappropriate at this stage to be putting funding down on the table for second and third years when we are not yet further along the negotiation process. We are going to provide transitional funding. We will be giving early advice—after all, 10 months ahead of the next financial year is pretty early—to the states about how we see that transitional funding being arranged.

I think that it is fair to all parties, including the federal taxpayer. I certainly hope that it achieves the intention of making sure that this process does not get stalled, that it keeps
moving along. That is why the government has proposed an agreement for up to three years and has nominated funding for the first year under that agreement.

I am concerned that the Australian Labor Party would endanger this legislation. I thank Senator Faulkner for his commitment to dealing with it on its return from the House of Representatives, but I am not sure whether he is alert to some of the facts. This bill having appropriated money for the first year, further funding was not provided for when the supply bills recently came before the parliament; consequently, if this bill is not passed by 30 June, the Commonwealth will not be able to make such payments until appropriation bill No. 2 for 1996-97 has been passed. That could delay payments to the states by five to six months. It could be expected to have a significant impact on negotiations with the states on longer term housing reform.

They are the facts of the matter. I urge you to think very carefully about that. If you are trying to achieve having appropriations for the second and third years included in this bill, on the grounds that that is going to help the states with certainty and an understanding of where they are going, you are actually potentially putting them at much greater risk by leaving them with cash shortages in the first five or six months of the next financial year.

I am giving you the advice that I have given you. I can only hope that, as the former government that was committed to this reform, you would not want to endanger the position of the states in this way. Nevertheless, the government will not be supporting this request.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —As a point of clarification, I thought I would make a few comments on the minister's mention of the reform process and just place on the record what process should not be delayed. speech.para:
The minister is right in saying this was a process which began with the previous government. To some measure, one shift is to
lease private sector dwellings which are then rented to tenants. In our opinion that is inefficient since it means the benefit does not ultimately accrue to the public. It seems more sensible for government to purchase a house outright than pay rent on it.

talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

Debate resumed from 21 May, on motion by

speech.speaker: Cook, Sen Peter

talk.start.para: —This is a debate on the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. I note that it is usual for a bill to be first presented to the House of Representatives before it comes to the Senate. There is in the second reading speech and explanatory memorandum no explanation as to why this bill is starting its passage through this parliament in the Senate, but I am sure that, in his reply, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Kemp) might wish to comment on that.

speech.para: This bill is substantially the same as a bill presented by the then Labor government in November last year, a bill which modified the arrangements for the export market development grant and which emanated from the 1995‐96 budget.

Before arriving in this chamber, the bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Just under a fortnight ago—in fact, last Wednesday week—that committee held an inquiry. A large number of industry organisations attended at relatively short notice to present comprehensive submissions, not only on this bill and the clauses it contains, but also—I am
sure they would not mind me saying this—to put a clear and firm stake in the ground.

They wanted to indicate that if, as rumours emanating from the ERC suggest, this scheme were to be abolished or severely hobbled, they, as organisations representing Australian industry, would be absolutely opposed to that step. They wanted to mark their opposition in advance of the government's consideration.

The committee's report was tabled today. The committee was unable to agree. I filed a minority report which, I think, more accurately reflects the views of industry than does the government achieved majority report. However, I will come to that in a moment. There is some background to the EMDG scheme that it is necessary to give first.

This is a scheme that is administered by Austrade, and, I might say, by and large, administered very well by that organisation. It was introduced by the Whitlam Labor government in 1974. Its purpose was to encourage Australian businesses to seek out new export markets for Australian goods and services. I might add, in parenthesis, it has been spectacularly successful at doing that.

The scheme itself currently provides taxable cash grants of up to $250,000 per annum based on the expenditure incurred by an Australian person or company seeking to create or expand exports of their products in overseas markets. Provided a person has incurred at least $30,000 of eligible expenditure in one year, they will be entitled to a grant. The grant is calculated at 50 per cent of eligible expenditure after the first $15,000. Claimants can receive up to eight grants and are subject to a performance test after two grants. Eligible expenditure includes up‐front marketing costs such as travel expenses, special promotional literature and overseas representations. Companies who record export sales above $25 million per year are ineligible to apply for the grant.

Between the years 1974 to 1991, 69,234 grants were made. Most EMDG grants are approximately $65,000 in value. In 1994-95, approximately 3,400 exporters received a total of $211 million under the scheme. Projections made in 1995 suggest that the scheme will
grow to around $292 million by the year 1998-99.

It is worth noting as well that some 70 per cent of all EMDG recipients are small and medium exporters with 25 or fewer employees. The last note in explanation is that, in 1994, as part of Working Nation, the Labor government announced the extension of the scheme for a further five years, thereby ultimately providing assistance to an expected 5,000 exporters per year.

It is, as I have said, a scheme that has been in existence for some time and it works very well. It works very well for a host of reasons, the most outstanding one being that the scheme is a very cost‐effective use of government expenditure. The scheme itself has been regularly reviewed. This is not a scheme that has gone on without its pulse being taken from time to time. The most recent review was in 1993 when the Treasury, the Department of Finance, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Price Waterhouse, with the assistance of Professor Bewley, an econometrist from the University of New South Wales, conducted a far‐reaching review of the scheme. It has also been reviewed by the Industry Commission and by a series of other bodies as well.

All, in substance, have agreed that this is an effective scheme. I might say that that is a rare conclusion when you consider that the key policy departments that conducted the review—the departments colloquially referred to as the bean counter departments, Finance and Treasury, who apply hard eyed rationalist thought and scrutiny to the effects of schemes such as this which use a large amount of public money—could not find fault with it at the end of the day. They gave it a tick, and in the stilted prose and understated commentary of Treasury, you would say that they, in fact, lauded the effectiveness of the scheme.
The first point—the most significant point—is that it is cost effective. It has been through the mill; no fault can be found with it, and it has been given a tick.

There are two other important things that I should say about it. Firstly, the amount of export that this expenditure of public monies creates is something that the committee that
reviewed this bill paid some attention to, and their comments are found, most importantly, on paragraph 46 of their report. They found that, for every dollar expended, the advantage returned to Australia was many times the amount outlaid.

The multiplier, as this is referred to, was found by the inquiry to be somewhere between 15 and 25 times. That is to say, for every dollar outlaid in the scheme, $15 to $25 in exports are achieved. Professor Bewley, who reviewed this as an econometrist, put the multiplier at about 10 times, but sometimes for more experienced firms it goes up to 25 times. It is worth noting as well that the Australian Information Industries Association reported, after surveying their own membership to see what the behaviour of the scheme was, that for experienced members—

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 6.50 p.m., I turn to the consideration of government documents.

speech.speaker: O'Chee, Sen Bill

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

In so doing, I draw the attention of the Senate to not only the change of practice of this government—which is to table for the scrutiny of parliament and the new joint committee on treaties all treaties and exchanges of notes that are relevant to treaties; in this case, it is an exchange of notes which amend an agreement between Australia and Singapore—but also the significant commitment that this government has to the Shoalwater Bay training area and to good cooperation with our neighbours.

For the benefit of honourable senators I should outline the basis of the document currently before the Senate. It is a document to amend a treaty between Australia and Singapore, which was made in February last year, to allow the Singaporean defence forces to use the Shoalwater Bay training area for armoured and infantry exercises rather than
the original proposals that were contained in the agreement of 17 February.

It is a sign that this government is sincere about parliamentary accountability that these notes were exchanged on 14 June this year and were tabled just four days later. I think the government deserves congratulations for the promptness with which it is bringing these matters to the attention of the Senate.

More importantly, what this agreement does is ensure very good cooperation with one of our close neighbours who is also a leading member of ASEAN. What Australia needs to do is have a meaningful relationship with our ASEAN neighbours. One of the failings of the previous government was that they almost went out of their way to insult and upset our neighbours. This government has a different view. We are not going to go kowtowing to anybody, but we do believe that you should have good relations.

The other important thing is that this agreement is a step towards the full utilisation of the Shoalwater Bay training facility. That is very important for the regional economy of Central Queensland, because full utilisation of that facility means more money will be flowing from outside the region into the local economy.

I can say, as somebody who was in Central Queensland and Rockhampton the week before last, that there is an enormous desire there to see every possible job created that this government can achieve. That must mean that we have to bring more and more income into the area. Use of these facilities means more people are going through the region; it means more people are going through the airport; it means more people are using the port facilities; it means, ultimately, a flow-on to the whole of the local economy.

This government will continue to improve the development of the economy of Central Queensland. I know that my colleague in the other place, Mr Marek, the member for Capricornia, is absolutely committed to finding every possible form of investment and every possible form of outside income to the economy of Central Queensland. He believes, as I do, that it is through the development of rural and regional Australia that we achieve
this nation's potential. That means that places like Rockhampton, as well as other places along the Queensland coast, deserve the consideration and respect of the government. That is what they are going to get from the coalition and that is what they are getting here.

More importantly, by ensuring that this facility is well used, we make it more feasible and more viable for the Australian Defence Force to keep using it. We reduce our share of the operating costs, and that is in the best interests of Australian taxpayers.

So I am very pleased to see that the document has been tabled. Without pre-empting the decisions of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I think it is a very fine document. I think the government should be congratulated not only for its strategic foresight but also for the promptness with which it has managed to table this document in the Senate—just four days after the exchange of notes.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I am speaking today to the Industry Commission's report entitled
Competitive tendering and contracting by public sector agencies
. On my brief scanning of a very large document,
it seems that there are some issues of concern, and some of these involve the concerns that the Greens have mentioned on a number of occasions; that is, the impact of competition policy and how it actually impacts across the board. I am afraid that the end approach—whatever you do and however you try to write your tendering document—tends to be reductionist. Some of the real costs of the outcomes of lowest cost tender‐type approaches are never met by the people who put out the tender, and they are certainly not met by the people who are offered the tender.

We know that during the competition policy legislation debate there was resistance from both sides of the chamber to placing any connection between policy goals from other areas into the competition policy legislation. So, if we are not careful, by 1998 we will basically fall into a situation where competition policy rules are okay but the other areas that may figure into the real costs of many of these decisions will not be taken into consideration. Other people, often the community, will be required to pick up the pieces. For instance, a recommendation in the report states:

If local governments in rural or remote areas give preferences to local suppliers or require contractors to use local resources, that should be set down fully in the tender documentation; all tenders, including in-house bids, should identify separately the additional price for being required to use local resources; and when the contract is awarded, any additional cost due to a requirement to use local resources should be announced.

That is interesting but, basically, some of the costs are not dollar costs; they could be environmental costs. For instance, I often use the example of frozen meals for hospitals which are transported from the city to the regions. It may well be that they are cheaper, but what is the real cost? It is not necessarily a dollar cost. What is the real cost to the person at the other end—the patient—who cannot order their meal a week in advance so that it gets there by road in a refrigerated truck? What is the real cost in employment opportunities to the local area? How do you actually build that into your tendering process? If you say that the onus is on the local regional council to make sure that they have
calculated the cost, how do you then provide them with the resources to do that? What do you mean by the real costs there? They are some of the examples.

I have also noticed that in this document there is some information in box No. 2 `The impact of CTC on quality'. A lot of the issues actually talk about price. Quite frankly, I could find you at least as many where the impact of implementing competitive tendering has actually indicated a decrease in quality. All you have to do is look at where these kinds of policies have been implemented in other parts of the world to come up with as many or more examples of serious shortfalls in quality and a lack of public control over what used to be publicly provided services.

There are a great many pitfalls I believe we can fall into by accepting this kind of document. I believe it is time that we start looking at the real implications of what we have signed up to under the competition policy legislation of July last year and start looking at the wide implications, instead of this reductionist approach that somehow or other saving the dollars tender by tender actually means that you have saved money for society. I do not think that is the case. I have yet to see a situation where the real costs of many of these decisions can actually be figured in. Quite frankly, our efforts to include those to be considered in what is public interest, and so on, were not adequately dealt with when this legislation was dealt with.

We have to go back to the legislation and look at more bodies, other than just the Industry Commission, and start looking at the real impacts of competitive tendering. How, for instance, do you make sure that the real hours required on a job are included in a tender? How do you do that adequately and then make sure that somebody else is not left with a price when the tender has been underquoted? Many people end up paying for that. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
