talker.name: Senator WOODS
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

talk.start.para: —At the election in March the Liberal and National Party coalition won an overwhelming mandate for a number of their policies—policies which were very clearly articulated to the electorate prior to the election. The overwhelming mandate was such that in the House of Representatives we finished with 94 seats compared with the Labor Party's miserable 49 seats. We received 54 per cent of the vote in that chamber. In the Senate we increased our representation by the maximum amount possible by winning the extra seat in New South Wales. We did this on the basis of clearly articulated policies, particularly relating to the environment, Telstra, industrial relations and tax reform.

speech.para: We seem to have had problems in the Senate in terms of the blocking of some of these issues by the Democrats. The Leader of the Democrats, Senator Kernot, claims a mandate to oppose the partial privatisation of Telstra, for example. There is a fundamental flaw in the claim that the increased vote in the Senate for the Democrats gives that party a mandate to oppose that partial privatisation because she conveniently avoids indicating that the Labor Party, the main opponent of the Telstra sale, registered a huge voting decline in the Senate throughout Australia. Both in negative percentage swings and in actual voting losses, the decline in support for the ALP in the Senate far outweighed the Democrat gains which were largely, if not totally, a recovery from the very poor Democrat polling in 1993 when Senator Coulter was the leader of the party.

If voters, particularly those who swung to the coalition so massively in the House of Representatives, had wished to indicate opposition to the Telstra sale, they had alternatives in the Senate, that is, to reduce the coalition vote, to increase the Labor vote or to increase Democrat support. None of these
opportunities was availed of. The coalition Senate vote increased significantly; the Labor vote declined dramatically; and the Democrat vote really did nothing more than recover from its disastrous results in 1993.

In terms of actual votes, the relatively small Democrat gains were engulfed by huge ALP losses and, in contrast, the coalition vote increased—an endorsement of its very clearly stated policies. We gained an extra seat in New South Wales—the only state in which such an opportunity occurred—and a further reinforcement of the electoral mandate. In the new Senate the coalition will hold 37 of the 76 seats and the ALP 29. That is a clear enough indication in itself as to which party should have that mandate.

The slogan that the Democrats ran on was the `Keep the bastards honest' policy. By any interpretation, keep the bastards honest means keep them to their word, hold them to the policies they clearly articulated. The obligation of the Democrats clearly is to ensure that promises are implemented, not to block their implementation. Even Don Chipp, the founder of the Democrats, said that this had to happen for the good of the nation. He also said that the Democrat party had no right whatsoever to oppose the government's agenda for reform. Mr Chipp went on to say that this was the appropriate response. Senator Kernot's staggering reply to that was to say that an analysis of the election result was proof that the Democrats were wanted by the voters to be an insurance policy in the Senate!

Senator Kernot's idea of insurance is strangely skewed. According to Senator Kernot, the 11 per cent of voters who voted for the Democrats gives them a right to ensure that what 48 per cent of people voted for, and what more than 50 per cent of people consistently support in the polls now, should be opposed altogether. I would hate to buy insurance from Senator Kernot. If she thinks that their scraping together 11 per cent of the vote means that Australians as a whole are asking her for insurance in the form of complete obstruction of the government's agenda, then she had better not go into the insurance business.

break.para: What are the arguments on Telstra that we hear? None of them is in the form of substantiation of claims by the Democrats. We have an ideological position and little more. The evidence from all over the world is that the benefits of privatisation, particularly for telecommunications services, are enormous. The Democrats make vague claims about the possibility of reduced services or increased charges, but the regulations that we have put into this bill actually offer much better protection to consumers than they have at present. There are penalties. For example, if you have to wait beyond the allotted date for an installation of a telephone, there are financial penalties on Telstra. Telstra's own estimates are that they are 30 per cent off the pace in terms of world leaders in telecommunication networks.

The benefits of competition are demonstrated all over the world—especially in the US and in Europe. What we have here from the Democrats is very clearly just an ideological stance and, make no bones about it, it is a hard left wing stance. Any pretensions the Democrats used to have to being a middle of the road party are gone. They are socialists through and through. We in this chamber actually thought socialism was dead. Some of our leaders in the coalition did say that socialist was not a way of describing the Labor Party. That may be true for the bulk of the Labor Party but it is certainly not true for the Democrats. The Democrats are now a socialist party now. They were described the other day as the watermelon party—green on the outside and red in the middle. It seems to be very appropriate. The description of them by one of my colleagues as Laborcrats not Democrats is also entirely appropriate.
Let us look at what the situation is in terms of privatisation around the world. Let me quote David Walker, who said:

You can pick the exact day when telecommunications privatisations slipped from the list of great global ideological controversies. On Monday, 13 June 1994 Fidel Castro agreed to sell half of its Cuban telecommunications system to a Mexican firm. When Castro, the last governing hero of deep red socialism, did that, the question of who should own the phone company lost its philosophical sting.
The debate everywhere is dissolving into consensus.

The combined Australian Left, led by the Australian Democrats and the Greens and followed by Labor, has not quite caught up even with Fidel Castro. They still want to block the bid but their arguments become more dated with every passing month.

As if that was not bad enough, as if that was not extreme enough, not only does Fidel Castro, the leader of the Left in the world, think this but so do the Albanians. The Albanians are now privatising part of their Telecom network. Even South Africa is moving to sell off some 25 per cent of its network. All around the world people are realising the benefits of privatisation.

The Democrats oppose the partial privatisation. They oppose the industrial relations bill. They oppose the sales tax changes. They oppose this and they oppose that. But for Senator Kernot it is not just words. She does put her money where her mouth is. In 17 divisions in this place since the election, the Democrats have opposed us in 16. The coalition government has lost 15 of these 17, I might add.

The only support we had from the Democrats was when there was a question of what should constitute a quorum on a joint committee appointment. That is not exactly one of the major issues facing the country but that is the only issue in 17 votes in this place on which the Democrats have in any way supported the government. Let them not pretend to be trying to uphold the mantle of democracy or freedom. This is blind ideology. It is blind obstructionism. It is opposition and blocking for its own sake. It cannot be called responsible. Senator Kernot seems to be giddy with the power that she now has but fortunately she is now losing her credibility.

There is no doubt at all in our minds that this is the true left wing party of Australia—the opportunists. When I first came into this place the Democrats were described to me as the `fairies at the bottom of the garden' party. I was sceptical of that description but, having seen them in action for a couple of years, and in particular in the last month or two, there is no doubt in my mind that that is a very fair description.

They are responsible not for keeping us, the government, honest but for trying to keep us dishonest, for opposing one of the largest mandates in history. The sadness is that Australia loses. The environment will lose because of the blocking of the environment legislation funding package. Telstra consumers will lose. In fact, everybody will lose.

It is time for the Democrats to come clean and abandon any pretence whatsoever to being the middle of the road party in Australia, to abandon any pretence to protecting the environment—they are vandalising the environment because of what they are blocking—and indeed to abandon any pretence to being Democrats in the sense of being representative of democracy. It is time they came clean and proclaimed themselves as the Laborcrat party—the socialist party of Australia.

speech.speaker: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to put on record my respect for and my sorrow at the passing of David Parker. David Parker AM, who has been a close friend of mine for the last 10 years or so, would certainly be very well-known to all residents of Canberra for his role not only in creating and sustaining the Canberra City Opera but also for the outstanding job he did as the head of the school of singing at the Canberra School of Music—a position he occupied from 1976 until a couple of years ago when he very reluctantly, I might say, retired and went to live in Cairns. He died at the weekend of a massive heart attack.

speech.para:
His obituary by Mr Hoffmann is in today's
Canberra Times
. But there are many other things that I would like to say about David Parker in addition to that obituary, which naturally deals very much with his outstanding role in Canberra. I must say I enjoyed not only watching his wonderful contribution to music education in this city but also seeing his involvement in bringing opera to as many people as possible in Canberra at a time when there were very great difficulties in doing so. I think opera ACT was having difficulties and it was very difficult for people in Canberra to hear much local quality operatic music.

break.para:
Certainly one of the great thrills of my life was to appear with him in the Canberra City Opera's production a few years ago of
Trial by Jury
when I was shadow minister for the arts. I guess I put my mouth where my shadow portfolio was and sang with him in
Trial by Jury
in the Great Hall of the parliamentrliament. David Parker sang the tenor role of the defendant and I was the judge.

He was not only a wonderfully accomplished singer but, in general terms, a great contributor to music and music education in Australia. His enthusiasm was not simply that of a teacher but, as I said, he provided easy access to opera and singing to whatever community he happened to live in. Canberra received the benefit of that for many years. In fact, I think it was in 1976 or so when he came to the Canberra School of Music, having first come to Australia on New Years Day in 1969. He had 27‐odd years in Australia, having had a distinguished singing career before that.

He was brought to Australia by the Australian Opera to be a principal tenor. Having had, I think, two seasons as principal tenor, he then became a touring artist with the ABC in Australia and New Zealand and sang with almost all the state operas—certainly Queensland, Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania—and distinguished himself in all those areas.

He sang in not only opera but also many other things. He sang with all the Australian orchestras. It is fascinating to see the list of people he sang with: the Welsh opera; the English National Opera, which was formerly Sadler's Wells; the Carl Rosa Opera; and touring companies in Ireland and in India, where he toured five times. He also was renowned for his roles in the great oratorios and masses, such as Britten's
War Requiem
and Berlioz's
Grand Mass for the Dead.

The distinguished artists he has sung with include Kiri Te Kanawa in
The Damnation of Faust
. I understand that he got better notices than she did on that occasion. He also sang with the wonderful late Australian singer Marie Collier and with Geraint Evans, Dame Gwyneth Jones and Simon Estes. He sang
under the batons of such outstanding conductors as Sir Thomas Beecham, Sir Adrian Boult and Van Otterloo.

Perhaps more significant has been the remarkable achievements of some of his students. I guess as a teacher of singing that would be the measure he would like to be judged against. Probably most outstanding at the moment in Australian terms would be Graham Pushee, who so recently showed us almost a new dimension in singing in the Australian Opera's production of
Julius Caesar
. Among his other achievements were being principal tenor at the Wexford international festival in Ireland.

He had an infectious, incredible sense of energy, fun and enthusiasm. This enthusiasm led him on many occasions, particularly when I was shadow minister for the arts, to give me the benefit of his advice, whether I sought it or not. He was a very determined person. I must admit that I found my ear being bashed in a very friendly but very determined way. David Parker had a clear view of what he thought we should be doing. It was always to be in Australia's best interests.

He was born in Wales. You could certainly tell that from the first words he uttered. He was very Welsh—very emotional, very excitable, very decent, very loving. He was married for 27 years to his widow, Marie van Hove, who herself played a distinguished role in the Canberra School of Music and before that was the ABC's most accomplished accompanist. I know that the musical partnership that existed through those years was a very intense and incredibly satisfying one to both of them. It is extraordinary that, in view of the way they had worked so hard together, David had been saying the six months of his retirement in Cairns, before unfortunately having this heart attack, were the most exciting and wonderful in his life.

It had been such an incredibly full life. Having been born in Skewen, near Cardiff in south Wales, in 1927 he had an outstanding education in music. He was a Seguin scholar at the Royal Academy of Music before going on to so many outstanding achievements in opera around the world. He leaves, apart from
Marie van Hove, his widow, three daughters by an earlier marriage: twins Nora and Rina, and Susan, all of whom live in the United Kingdom but are coming back for his funeral on Saturday, which will be in Cairns.

All I can say in conclusion is that there are very few people who have left such an incredible impact on me as David Parker did. As I said, his bubbling enthusiasm sometimes carried him—some people might say—over the edge in presenting his case. Certainly some people in Canberra resented his determination to do things in what he believed to be the right way. In my view, his heart was always in the right place, even though it was his heart that ultimately let him down. His enthusiasm for Australia was outstanding. His love of music was overwhelming. He will be sadly missed.

question.speaker: Woodley, Sen John

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 28 March 1996:

question.para: With reference to section 1121 of the Social Security Act 1991 which provides, in part, that where a liability is secured over an asset that is comprised of both an assessable asset and an exempt asset, the liability is to be apportioned and that part of the liability that relates to the exempt asset is not allowed to be deducted from the client's assessable assets; and with reference to the case of Little (1 October 1992) in which the Social Security Appeals Tribunal interpreted section 1121A in such a way as not to apportion a liability that was secured over an asset that was comprised of both an exempt and a non‐exempt asset:
(1) How is the department currently administering this provision.
(2) Why has this approach been adopted.
(3) How many people have been assessed under this provision in the most recent 12 months for which figures are available.

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Only assets used in carrying out primary production and the liabilities directly related to carrying out those activities are taken into account. This means that if a person's home is on farmland used for primary production activities, only the farmland is included with other farming assets in the total primary production assets held; if the farm, including the home, is encumbered, only the portion of the liability related to primary production activities is included with other primary production liabilities.

(2) The department did not agree with the Social Security Appeals Tribunal's interpretation of section 1121A in the Little case. Amendments to the legislation were contemplated to put the matter beyond doubt but they were not pursued because of legal advice that the existing legislation was clear, and that the department's administration of the provision was correct.
(3) The department does not maintain statistics on the number of assessments under section 1121A.

question.speaker: Jones, Sen Gerry

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 23 April 1996:

question.para: With reference to the meeting in March 1996 of the Senior Officers' Group of the Australasian Police Ministers' Council (APMC) to discuss implementation of uniform gun laws throughout Australia:
(1) How many interest groups responded to the working paper on gun laws released following the APMC meeting in Launceston, Tasmania, in November 1995.
(2) In brief terms what was the response to the working paper and what suggestions from these groups will be considered by the APMC.
(3) Has the Council met to discuss uniform gun laws since the November 1995 meeting; if so, what was the outcome of any discussion.
(4) What is the gun law agenda to be discussed by the APMC at its scheduled meeting in May 1996.
(5) Will the Government seek assurances from the State Governments that gun law proposals endorsed by the APMC are followed up with uniform legislation in each State.

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) At the national level 16 interest groups—drawn from all States and Territories—were consulted and responded to the working paper. Interest groups such as the Shooting Sports Council of Victoria, Firearms Dealers Association, Tasmanian Firearms Owners Association, Sporting Shooters Association of Australia and the Shooters Party were involved. Additionally, each jurisdiction also consulted with interest groups at the local level. The outcome of these consultations were incorporated into the working paper.

(2) The responses by interest groups to the working paper varied from supportive to negative. All responses were taken into account in preparing the Commonwealth proposals for the APMC meeting on 10 May 1996.

(3) Following the tragic events at Port Arthur, the APMC held a Special Firearms Meeting in Canberra on 10 May 1996 to discuss proposals for effective nationwide control of firearms. The Commonwealth and the States and Territories agreed upon a series of resolutions for the effective nationwide control of firearms. Copies of the resolutions have been provided to all members of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

(4) The APMC is scheduled to meet again in July 1996. It is expected that this meeting will provide an opportunity for Ministers to detail their jurisdiction's progress in implementing the resolutions Council agreed to on 10 May 1996.

(5) At the Special Firearms Meeting, Council agreed to minimum standards in relation to firearms control which will be applied in each jurisdiction. All jurisdictions agreed that necessary amendments to legislation/regulations will be completed as soon as possible.

The procedures were the use of mixed gas diving to depths down to 200 metres using both open circuit and semi‐closed circuit sets. Initial information was reported by the staff of Prince Henry Hospital. Further details came from a Fun Dive seminar.

(7) All relevant HMAS
Penguin
documented advice given to WorkCover on the safety of recreational mixed gas diving has been provided under FOI to Mr Cason. A complete report of Lieutenant Strack's comments has also been provided.

(10)(a)(i) Yes. Technical Divers International (TDI), the International Association of Nitrox and Technical Divers (IANTD), and the American Nitrox Divers Incorporated (ANDI) are three associations who offer mixed gas recreational diving instruction.

ety(UHMS), the South Pacific Underwater Medicine Society (SPUMS), the Diver Alert Network (DAN), Diver Emergency Service (DES) and recreational diving bodies such as the Professional Association of Diving Instructors (PADI), the Federation of Australian Underwater Instructors (FAUI), National Association of Underwater Instructors (NAUI). talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 May 1996:

question.para:
(1) With reference to each of the financial years 1985 to 1994 inclusive: (a) in how many bankruptcies has the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) been: (i) the petitioning creditor, and (ii) a supporting creditor; and (b) how many of the taxation
assessments resulting in bankruptcies in each year were handled by the ATO (Australia‐wide).
(2) Does the Taxation Commissioner have any guidelines issued to his officers with respect to the settlement of taxation debts; if so, what are those guidelines; if not, why not.
(3) What are the Taxation Commissioner's guidelines with respect to the settlement of taxation debts on a commercial basis.
(4) Does the Taxation Commissioner take into account the interests of other creditors when: (a) taking bankruptcy proceedings; and (b) determining whether to accept an offer made by a taxpayer.
(5) Is it the policy of the ATO to push taxpayers into bankruptcy in order to close the particular file; if not, what is the purpose of forcing taxpayers into bankruptcy.

(6) Is it the policy of the Taxation Commissioner to assess a particular taxpayer's position in the situation of an unpaid taxation debt with a view to maximising the benefit to revenue; if so, why does the ATO refuse so many proposals for settlement.

answer.speaker: Short, Sen Jim

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1)(a) & (b) It is not possible to provide the specific information requested by the honourable senator, as that information is not kept by the ATO. Legal action to recover a debt, which may ultimately result in the sequestration of an individual debtor's estate in bankruptcy or the liquidation of a corporate debtor, is commenced in quite a number of cases. However, that action may not always be pursued to its ultimate conclusion because the debtor may pay in full or may enter into an acceptable arrangement to pay a debt over time.

In some cases, debtors present their own petition for bankruptcy. There are also cases where other creditors of the ATO debtor may initiate legal recovery action and pursue a debt to bankruptcy or liquidation (the ATO will figure as a creditor in a majority of bankruptcy/liquidation cases given the nature of taxation and its application to the majority of Australians). In those cases, the ATO will either lodge a proof of debt with the official receiver, a trustee in bankruptcy or a liquidator or will ask the Court to be substituted as the petitioning creditor in appropriate instances.

The Commissioner has provided the following information for each of the years ended 30 June 1992, 1993, 1994 and 1995 in relation to cases finalised as a result of legal action and cases on hand and subject to some form of insolvency action (that is, corporate liquidation or individual bankruptcy). Information prior to these years is not available.
(1)(a)(i) The following table shows number of cases finalised as a result of legal action for the years 1992 to 1995:
(1)(a)(ii) The following table shows number of cases on hand and subject to some form of insolvency action for the years 1992 to 1995

(2) ATO officers are aware of the policy and procedural documents and the various Rulings relating to activities that impact the collection of overdue debts issued by the Commissioner (where those activities relate to collection of the total debt, including the additional charges for late payment imposed by legislation). In the main, these documents are available to the public and set out policy and guidelines for debtors and also for staff who may be considering:‐

para.tab: action to estimate some outstanding debts;
requests for time to pay outstanding tax debts by instalments;
proposals by corporations to enter into agreements to pay;
requests for remission of additional charges for late payment;
writing off debts that are irrecoverable at law, irrecoverable because the debtor is without assets or uneconomical to recover;
claims by debtors that payment of their debts will cause serious hardship; and
instituting some form of legal recovery action, including issuing `garnishee' notices or proceeding to bankruptcy/liquidation.

answer.para: (3) The Commissioner is in a vastly different position to a commercial creditor in that he cannot refuse to deal with a debtor or withhold supply. Invariably, the debtor will be required to lodge a subsequent income tax return and potentially, incur another debt, or be required to remit monthly amounts (for example, sales tax or amounts that have been deducted from the wages of employees).

In a private agreement between a commercial creditor and a debtor which involves acceptance of a lesser sum in full satisfaction of a debt, the commercial creditor, in consideration for payment of the lesser sum, can opt not to deal with the debtor again (and would reduce the chance of any future financial loss) and would usually grant a legal discharge of the balance of the debt such that, in law, it no longer existed. The Commissioner, however, does not have the same power.

The Commissioner has advised the present policy of the ATO is not to agree to an informal `commercial' settlement of taxation debts. Debtors can exercise their rights under the formal `settlement' provisions of either Part X of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 or Part 5.3A of the `Corporations Law' if they wish to seek a settlement.

ATO collection staff are aware of the formal `settlement' provisions of both the Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Part X) and the `Corporations Law' (Part 5.3A). These provisions are an alternative to bankruptcy or liquidation and:‐

para.tab: provide relief for an insolvent debtor;
generally treat all creditors equally; and
provide for a fair and equitable distribution under an arrangement that can be voted on by all creditors.

answer.para:
The Commissioner is an unsecured creditor in relation to taxation debts and collection staff are aware he has the same discretion as any other creditor to either agree to, or oppose, any proposed deed put forward to creditors under either Part X of the Bankruptcy Act or Part 5.3A
of the `Corporations Law'. Any proposal put forward is considered by staff on its merits.
When considering whether or not to vote in favour of a particular deed, staff generally take into account issues such as:

para.tab: normal commercial practices to the extent it is appropriate to apply those practices to the recovery of taxation debts;
the likely net return;
the recommendations of the trustee or deed administrator;
whether there are alternate remedies a trustee or administrator should pursue (for example, whether directors of a company have been involved in insolvent trading);
in the case of a company deed, whether the directors of the company have a past history of putting companies into administration to avoid their responsibilities as directors;
public interest considerations in relevant cases; and
the particular restrictions of any proposed arrangement.

answer.para: The Commissioner has advised policy in this area is currently under review as part of the overall review of ATO debt collection policies.

(4) The Commissioner has an obligation to collect the revenue; he expects taxpayers (including corporates) to arrange their affairs so that they can meet their liabilities as and when they fall due for payment. If a tax debt is not paid by the due date for payment and the debtor does not contact the ATO, the Commissioner can only make the assumption the debtor is not going to pay and put in place action to deal with that debt.

That action may include personal, telephone or written contact, the issue of garnishee notices, the issue of orders preventing a debtor's departure from Australia until a debt is paid, legal action up to and including the bankruptcy of an individual or the liquidation of a company, accepting payment of the debt over time, recovering from the personal assets of company directors, writing‐off debts considered uneconomical to pursue and inviting applications for a release from income tax and fringe benefits tax debts, which are determined by a Taxation Relief Board.

(a) The decision to proceed to bankruptcy or liquidation is not taken lightly. In some cases, it is relevant to consider the impact of bankruptcy on other creditors, but generally, this could not be said to be a dominant consideration. Indeed, it is unlikely commercial creditors would consider the impact of their actions to recover on the Commonwealth revenue.

(b) The interests of all creditors are considered under the alternates provided in the Bankruptcy Act 1966 and the `Corporations' Law
.
An informal
`commercial' settlement by its very nature would not reflect the interests of other creditors. The Commissioner advised this is one of a number of issues under consideration for the policy review on the question of `commercial' settlements.

(5) The Commissioner advises it is not his policy to push taxpayers into bankruptcy in order to close the particular file. He indicated that on average, an administration takes three years to finalise.

Bankruptcy is only one of a number of ways of dealing with debts and is a valid activity that is used by commercial creditors. The Commissioner does not pursue bankruptcy as a matter of course; on the other hand, he does not resile from using this mechanism when considered appropriate. Bankruptcy does provide some benefits for debtors in that they can start afresh without any financial worries when their bankruptcy is finalised.
The onus is on debtors to demonstrate they cannot pay on time and the Commissioner expects those debtors to approach him with an offer of payment. That offer should:‐

para.tab: set out the reasons for non‐payment on time;

provide a detailed statement of the current financial position (including details of what steps have been taken to obtain funds to meet the debt and what arrangements are in place to pay other creditors);

provide sufficient information to satisfy him payment can be made by instalments without the debt escalating other than by the amount of the accruing additional charges (which would mean debtors will need to be able to show the steps taken to ensure future debts will be met as and when they fall due); and
be accompanied by an initial payment as a sign of genuineness and commitment to pay.

answer.para: (6) The decision on the most appropriate recovery action is very subjective and is based on a perception of how best to deal with a particular case to maximise the return to revenue. That subjective decision making process takes into account a number of issues, including:‐

para.tab: the circumstances that led to the inability to pay and the effect of requiring immediate payment;
the current financial position and other current payment obligations;

the offer made and the ability to meet payment of the debt and the additional charges for late payment imposed by legislation on those terms without seriously impacting on the ability to meet other obligations;
whether there is a likely risk to the revenue by accepting payment by instalments;
the solvency of the debtor and arrangements made with other arm's length creditors to pay debts;
compliance with other taxation obligations or commitments (for example, whether lodgments are up to date) and the history of the debtor's prior dealings with the ATO; and
whether there are alternative economic collection options that may see payment in a shorter time frame (for example, the use of `garnishee' provisions).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 8 May 1996:

question.para: (1) What is the current anticipated completion date for the Sydney West Airport.

(2) What are the anticipated completion dates of the following stages of this project: (a) pre‐design stage; (b) design stage; (c) planning stage; (d) environmental approval stage; (e) statutory approval stage; (f) acquisition of lands process; (g) calling for and awarding of tenders; (h) construction stage; and (i) commissioning stage.

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para:
—The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided
the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) A timetable for the development of Sydney's second airport will be prepared in light of the Government's review of the outcome of the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) process for the new airport.

The Government has decided to expand the EIS to encompass an updated environmental assessment of Holsworthy, as well as Badgerys Creek, as a possible site for Sydney's second major airport. Should the environmental impacts of developing a major airport at Badgerys Creek prove to be unacceptable, it is important that an alternative site has been considered.

Preparation for the EIS process for the new airport has already commenced. The Department of Transport and Regional Development recently advertised for organisations interested in providing consultancy services for various aspects of the EIS. The extent of future EIS related contracts will be determined once the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency has finalised the guidelines for the EIS.

The properties comprising the Sydney West Airport site at Badgerys Creek have all been acquired by the Commonwealth. The Holsworthy site is also already owned by the Commonwealth. This ensures minimum delay in the commencement of construction once the EIS process is finalised and the consequential Government decisions have been made.
